title: work-taking-place-upgrade-drift-path-musselburgh-wallyford
story: Wimpey East Scotland said the improvements to the walkway, next to its Almond Park development at Pinkie, got under way last Wednesday and would take about four to five weeks to complete.A new surfaced path will be laid three metres in width to ensure it is fully accessible for a range of users.The section of pathway, which extends from the car park at Pinkie Terrace in Musselburgh to the underpass at the railway line, will also benefit from new street lighting which will be installed.There is no access to The Drt during the work in the interests of health and safety, the company stressed.Pauline Mills, land  planning director for Taylor Wimpey East Scotland, said: ldquoWe do hope these path improvement works will be welcomed locally and we apologise in advance for any inconvenience they may experience while the current path is closed to all users.ldquoAn information postcard will be distributed to all properties within the Almond Park development this week to let them know about the work that will be taking place.ldquoShould anyone have any concerns, please email sarah.patonbutler@taylorwimpey

title: msp-praises-volunteer-centre-critical-lifeline-visit
story: The comments follow South Scotland MSP Craig Hoyrsquos visit to the Tranent-based facility.The centre is a third-sector interface which provides support to voluntary organisations across East Lothian through partnership projects.This has included working in partnership with Musselburgh-based Paragon Products to deliver cleaning supplies to support the opening of community and third-sector organisations.During his visit, Mr Hoy met with the centrersquos chief officer Maureen Allan, discussing some of the challenges and opportunities the easing of lockdown restrictions had presented for the voluntary sector.The High Street facility also operates a childrenrsquos befriending service, supported hospital discharge programme, community taskforce service for those isolated during lockdown, a free community pantry and provides access to computers for those who struggle with technology.Working with East Lothian Councilrsquos connected communities team, the countyrsquos health and social care partnership and other third-sector organisations in the county, the volunteer centre provides free, confidential advice and support for residents and support for small local third-sector groups.Mr Hoy said: ldquoVolunteer Centre East Lothian has become an essential service for many residents and organisations during this dficult period. The staff and volunteers are a critical leline for local residents.ldquoI would like to extend my thanks to Maureen for welcoming me to the centre and for her wider work fundraising.Maureen said: ldquoOur communities, the third sector and statutory partners have shown how much can be achieved by working together. The pandemic made a lot of people re-evaluate their lives. Many residents volunteered their time and it was great to see the real community spirit that has been lost over the years resurface.To contact the centre, call  , email info@volunteereastlothian.org.uk or visit volunteereastlothian.org.uk

title: looking-back-turnpike-tolls-east-lothian
story: The first turnpike road was set up in  for sections of the Great North Road in Hertfordshire, Bedfordshire and Huntingdonshire.In spite of some early problems, with angry yokels kicking open the turnpikes or beating up the tollkeepers, these turnpikes soon became a profitable venture they spread, like a contagion, all over England and Wales.The Act of Union in  opened the Scottish Border to the turnpike road system, the first one being constructed on a road in Midlothian in .East Lothian also developed a healthy population of turnpikes and tollhouses, supported by the local authorities but far from popular among the locals.There was a turnpike on the main road through Aberlady, with the tollhouse still standing to this day.There was at least one turnpike road through Haddington one near the Town Hall at Dunbarrsquos High Street one on the main road between Dunbar and North Berwick, and two more at Belhaven and Kirk Hill near Dunbar.Usually, a turnpike and tollhouse was put up by the authorities, with the top bid being pocketed for use in road maintenance, and the poor tollkeeper left to a boring and onerous task collecting the tolls to recompensate himself.When I was researching my book Phillimorersquos East Lothian, I noted a quaint card of lsquoCleikum Toll, Dunbarrsquo: a bucolic scene of a small cottage, with a woman standing in the doorway and a shepherd, eight sheep and a sheepdog passing it by. The card had superior artistic merit and I wanted to make use of it in the book, which was to include a number of old cards by the celebrated North Berwick postcard artist Reginald Phillimore.The problem, however, was that no information was forthcoming where this obscure cottage had been or how it had earnt sufficient fame to be depicted by Phillimore.The book was published in  without lsquoCleikum Tollrsquo being featured.The purchase of another Edwardian postcard belatedly solved the mystery in August : it turned out that the careless Phillimore had got the name wrong, since it was not lsquoCleikum Tollrsquo but lsquoCleikimin Tollrsquo!And indeed, inquiries demonstrated that this turnpike and tollhouse had been standing at the cross between the road from Dunbar to Spott and the road from Broxburn to Belton. It is likely there were two turnpikes, one on each road. The tollhouse was said to be very old, quite possibly constructed in the first half of the th century.In early Victorian times, the tollgate system kept flourishing all over Britain. In rural west Wales, there were full-scale riots in  after a number of novel turnpikes had been erected, something the locals disapproved of. Men dressed as women attacked the turnpikes and beat up the tollkeepers, and it was only with dficulty they could be pacied.Cleikimin Toll was spared such indignities, however: it was still operational at the time of the Ordnance Survey of -. The name-book of this survey [OS    ] refers to it as a ldquoA Toll Bar at a junction of roads situated about half a mile south of the town of Dunbar.A note explains Cleikimin as a name usually applied to a cheap public house, where a Cleik [Scottish for fish-hook] was supposed to have been made use of to pull the customers inside.The arrival of the railways did much damage to the old tollgate system all over Britain: as a result, the road toll revenue plummeted and the tollkeepers grumbled incessantly.The Scottish municipal authorities realised the old-fashioned turnpikes were on the way out, and by  they were all gone.The tollhouse at Cleikimin Toll stood well into Edwardian times, being admired as a quaint relic of olden days. It survived the Great War but was destroyed not long after in a scheme for widening the A. Thistly Cross Roundabout today stands on the spot.

title: nicola-sturgeon-covid-update-today-time-watch
story: The Scottish government came under fire when people reported problems using the NHSScotland Covid Status App after its release on Thursday.Vaccine passports is just one of a number of changes introduced over the past seven days, with new travels rules coming into effect from Monday.Scotland announced last month that it would maintain a four nation approach to travel despite initial hesitancy to do so.It means that the same rules apply to international travel wherever in the UK you are visiting.Heres everything you need to know about todays update including what the first minister might say...Nicola Sturgeons Covid update will take place today at around :pm.The exact timing of the announcement will depend on the previous three items on the agenda running to time.You can watch the first ministers Covid update on Scottish ParliamentTV.Alternatively it will be streamed live on the Scottish governments social media s and the SNP will live tweet the statement.The briefing will also be broadcast live on the BBC Scotland channel from :pm.The first minister will as always provide an update on the figures, as well as the progress in vaccination.She is als likely to touch on the implementation of the vaccine passport scheme and perhaps the new status app.Following Nicola Sturgeons statement there will be a ministerial update on the Covid Recovery Strategy, so the first minister may indicate in her speech what this strategy may include.

title: north-berwick-home-branded-grand-designs-experiment-approved
story: Architect Robin Sutherland saw his vision of a family home on North Berwickrsquos High Street turned down by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning committee.The proposals, recommended for approval by planning officers, were rejected by a single vote.Mr Sutherland, who works in the town, appealed to Scottish Ministers to see the plans given the green light.Rosie Leven, the reporter appointed by the Scottish Ministers, gave the planned three-storey building at  High Street and land to the north the go ahead.Neighbours overlooking the proposed three-bedroom house had objected to the planned property, which measures just over four metres wide and  metres long, on the grounds of privacy.Mrs Leven attached a condition to the approval that a balustrade should be included on the roof terrace.She said: ldquoI consider that the proposed first floor kitchen doors and roof terrace are part of the main living space of the proposed house and are likely to be more regularly used, during a larger proportion of the day, than the bedroom windows.ldquoI consider that it is from those first floor windows spaces that there is the greatest potential for an adverse effect on neighbouring residential amenity.ldquoIn this respect, the appellant has suggested that a condition could be placed on the consent to require a . metre balustrade around the three open sides of the roof terrace.ldquoIn the circumstances, I find that such a balustrade would help to reduce the ability for overlooking, both from the roof terrace itself and from the double doors to the kitchen.ldquoTaking this into account, I accept that there may be some overlooking from and to the proposed bedroom window, but with the addition of a balustrade, I consider that the overall impact on the amenity of the neighbouring properties would not be signicantly adverse.Concerns had also been raised about whether the proposed building was in keeping with the character of the town centre.The Reporter noted that traditional buildings ldquodominate the area but added ldquothere are dferent heights and styles of building.She said there was ldquono consistent building line on Forth Street and the character is one of buildings offset from each other, providing interesting views and angles.The proposals originally went before the local authorityrsquos planning committee in January, with six of the  councillors voting to reject the plans.Councillor Jane Henderson was joined by fellow North Berwick Coastal ward members Jim Goodfellow and Jeremy Findlay in speaking out against the plans.She told the committee that the width of the home would be ldquonot much wider than a shipping container, my goodness gracious.She said: ldquoI am not convinced this is the best place for a Grand Designs experiment, adding: ldquoJust because theoretically it can be done does not make it right.Grand Designs is a popular and long-running home improvements television show presented by Kevin McCloud where unique and daringly designed homes are built.

title: nicola-sturgeon-covid-update-today-learned-announcement
story: Covid cases in Scotland have fallen in recent weeks, which is due immune response fromboth vaccination and an element of people being infected with Covid, according to the first minister.The Scottish government was criticised last week after many people had problems with downloading the NHS Scotland Covid Status app.Changes to the rules surroundinginternational travel also came into force as Scotland chose to participate in a four nations approach.It means that the same rules will apply wherever you travel in the UK.As Scotland continues its journey towardspost pandemic recovery, heres what we learned from Nicola SturgeonsCovid update today...The first minister confirmed that there would be no changes to the "albeit, limited regulations" still in place in Scotland.This is because, according to the first minister, the numbers have continued to fall.However, she also said that despite falling cases, the infection rate still remainsrelatively high which is of concern as we head into the winter months.It is for this reason that the current limited measures, such as mask wearing,will remain in place in Scotland.Explaining this, the first minister said: "the level of infection, though falling, remains relatively high and so we consider that it is prudent at this stage, as we approach winter, to keep in place the remaining mitigations, face coverings for example, for a further period."A total of , daily cases were recordedtoday, a slight increase on yesterdays figures which were below ,.The "signicant and sustained fall" in cases is now being reflected in the number of hospital admissions, according to the first minister.As a result, Nicola Sturgeon continues to remainoptimistic about the general downward trend in numbers, following a period of daily figures topping , throughout August and early September.Describing this as a relief, she said: "Given that cases are continuing to fall, we hope and expect that the number of people in hospital will decline further. We also expect that the number of people dying from Covid will reduce."The mitigation measures currently in place in schools areunder review, particularly whether pupils will continue to have to wear masks in schools after the October break.The body conducting the review is expected to come to a decision on such measures later this afternoon and will then advise the Scottish government.The first minister added that"should they advise that any easing is possible following the October half-term, the Scottish Government will consider this carefully and advise schools of any changes as soon as possible."Nicola Sturgeon acknowledged the problems releated to the app, particularly the issues downloading vaccination status on Thursday and Friday, and apologised.Explaining the source of the problem, the first minister said:"Essentially the high level of demand after the launch of the app ndash combined with an error in one part of the NHS system ndash meant that information wasnrsquot being sent quickly enough from the NHS system to the app."She added: "Indeed, I can report that the initial backlog of people waiting for their information to be matched had been cleared by Saturday lunchtime."Nicola Sturgeon confirmed that although initially the app faced signicant problems, it now works well.She therefore encouraged everyone to download or order their vaccine passport as soon as possible.

title: maths-teacher-stars-popular-tv-show-countdown
story: Steven Grady appeared on two episodes of the Channel  show, which sees two contestants compete through three types of rounds ndash a letters round, numbers round and conundrum round.Mr Grady won the numbers round on his first episode and tied with his opposition during the numbers round on his second episode.Countdown is hosted by Anne Robinson ndash the first female host of Channel s longest running series.Contestants stay on the show until they either lose a game or retire undefeated as an lsquoOctochamprsquo after eight wins.Mr Grady won his first episode - against a contestant who had previously won four games. In his second episode, he lost - on a crucial conundrum.Mr Grady, who lives in Edinburgh, joined the PL staff team in August .He said: ldquoI applied for Countdown in June  but, due to Covid restrictions, I couldnrsquot get down to the studio.ldquoI applied after watching a few shows through lockdown and thinking I would like having a go at it. I eventually got a filming date for early August."ldquoIt was great fun to film. I was excited to share it with my students and it caused a buzz in the school. Some teachers showed it to their class and had the students playing along!ldquoThe students keep asking how much money I won and find it hilarious that I only won a teapot!ldquoItrsquos not being used as a teapot, though ndashjust an ornament and a good keepsake!Gavin Clark, headteacher, said: ldquoWe are delighted Steven has shared Preston Lodgersquos focus on literacy and numeracy with a national audience.ldquoWersquore really proud of Steven and look forward to seeing him in future game shows!The episodes are available on All .

title: calls-made-post-covid-review-gp-needs-wallyford-houses-approved
story: East Lothian Councils planning committee granted detailed planning permission for the new Taylor Wimpey homes as part of development of the site south of Wallyford.However, concerns were raised that no new discussions had been held with health chiefs over the need for additional GP services to serve the new housing.Musselburgh GP practices have comeunder pressure in recent years, as newbuilds bring more families into the area, leading to a number of calls for action from the community and politicians.Councillor Norman Hampshire, planning convenor, told the virtual planning committee meeting that he was surprised no talks with health bosses had been held since the early days of the masterplan for the -hectare site, which was first lodged in .He said: ldquoObviously from the timesince the masterplan was approved and these applications, a lot has happened: the growth in population,plus the cases of Covid and pressures on GP practices in the Musselburgh area.ldquoYou would think there would have been at least further discussion with the NHS regarding the current situation.David Taylor, from the councilrsquos planning department, said that the number of houses planned for the land was still well below those approved in the masterplan when NHS bosses were consulted.He said that the original masterplanapproved had included the formation of , houses, adding that to date only  had come forward.ldquoThis application will take it over , but it is still short of the , which discussions took place on during the planning application in principle on medical provision, he said.Councillors approved the new houses on land in the south east of the site.However, ward councillor Colin McGinn called on NHS Lothian and the Scottish Government to urgently assess the situation at the Wallyford development.He said: ldquoMy overarching point is the provision of medical facilities for this area and the concerns we have had particularly over the last  months and prior to that over the primary care services.ldquoI want to take this opportunity today to call on NHS Lothian and the Scottish Governmentto conduct a full appraisal of what we need because clearly what wersquove got is running out of space and itrsquos not going to meet the need of a developing community."This problem is not going to go away.The committee also unanimously approveddetails for  new homes at Windygoul in Tranent,which forms part of a wider development to the south of the town, where construction on part of the site is already under way.The -house development is on a site next to Ormiston Road and farmland to the south of Tranent.

title: haddington-pipe-band-launches-calendar-help-celebrate-40th-birthday
story: Haddington Pipe Band is toasting its th year and released its annual calendar in the town last Saturday.Alastair Bruce, a board member of the band, was pleased to say the calendar, which has a theme of lsquoAnd the Band Playedrsquo, had proven popular.He said: ldquoThe response has been great. We have had really good support from sponsors again and we just launched it last Saturday.ldquoWe got a good number of folk turning up at that and now I am just about to take it out to the shops and other outlets who are selling it for us.ldquoThe Loft has got the exhibition of the calendarrsquos photographs and that is there until January.ldquoObviously, wersquove not been able to play this last couple of years until the last month or so.ldquoWe were not able to take new shots so we have looked back over the last few years and sourced photographs of the band in action.ldquoThe theme is lsquoAnd the Band Playedrsquo and each month is us playing at galas, at a wedding, a festival, on stage in France and just dferent types of events that we have covered here and further afield over the years.Mr Bruce was expecting some of the calendars to make their way over the English Channel but that is not the only far-flung destination.He said: ldquoOne of the first calendars is going to Australia. That is fairly typical and they have gone to India, Spain, the USA, Canada, Africa ndash itrsquos really good.Photographs have been provided by regular supporters of the band, including Nick Callaghan and Garry Menzies.The pipe band attracts members aged from eight to , with more than a dozen pipers and a number of drummers.However, the past  months have seen the band sidelined when it comes to getting out in the community.Mr Bruce told the Courier that plans to mark the th year were being drawn up, although it depended upon coronavirus restrictions remaining eased.He added: ldquoWe would probably have made a bit more of a song and dance about itthings had been dferent.ldquoWe are back out playing now and were at the farmersrsquo market last Saturday, as well as doing the launch.ldquoWe have been to a wedding and doing other things as well.ldquoWe have not been able to practise together but have been doing Zoom calls every week, which sounds ridiculous but we have been doing that and playing on the chanter rather than the full pipes.The calendar, which costs pound, is a key part of the bandrsquos fundraising, with the money going to unorms, instruments, tuition and other initiatives.Mr Bruce added: ldquoPeople in the band donrsquot pay for their unorms, there is no subscription to be a band member and we try to keep it so anybody can join and play.ldquoWe provide instruments and all that costs quite a lot of money.ldquoThe secret of the calendar is that we try to get something that people are happy to have on their walls.ldquoPeople buy it to support us but we want to have good photographs so people enjoy having it on their walls.

title: insurers-cover-distressed-dogs-owners-return-office
story: With many people working from home during the pandemic, many new pets were purchased due to the excess time at home. But now most people are ing to the office, and pets are not used to being left alone.Pet owners may not realise that their insurance policy could include cover for veterinary treatment for their distressed pets, financial information firm Defaqto said.Behaviour cover is designed to pay for therapy to treat emotional distress which could be caused by separation anxiety now that some owners are no longer working from home.Defaqto found more insurers are now offering behaviour cover as part of their pet insurance products, compared with the start of the coronavirus pandemic.Nearly half of dog insurance policies now include full cover for behaviour, compared with % in February .Defaqto cautioned that insurers will exclude cover for claims where the behavioural illness could have been prevented by proper training and socialising.Brian Brown, consumer finance expert at Defaqto, said: ldquoDogs provided much-needed companionship for their owners throughout the pandemic and for those that started le in lockdown, they have never known any dferent.ldquoIt is not surprising then that some dogs are anxious when they are being left alone for the first time and displaying destructive behaviour. The good news is that this is treatable and insurers have stepped up to increase their cover for this.ldquoMany insurers offer free vet helplines where you can get advice over the phone, evenyou donrsquot have to make a claim. If you find you donrsquot have insurance cover, speak to the animal charities to get advice.

title: christmas-shortages-2021-homemade-christmas-gift-ideas
story: Covid- and Brexit are among contributing factors, while an escalating dispute over fishing rights has led French fishing representatives to threaten a blockade at Calais to stop exports to the UK.Current issues have been put down to a "transition period" by Boris Johnsons administration, which they say will not cause "much risk" at Christmas.However, asindustry experts deemChristmas shortages "a certainty", making your own presents could help you to avoid potential delays or disappointment.Not only that, but family and friends are sure to appreciate the time andeffort that goes into creating ahand crafted gt.Here are some ideas for homemade presents this Christmas...The festive period is a time for eating, so what better than cooking up a big batch of homemade jam or chutney for your loved ones.Start saving your jars now and by Christmas you will have plenty to fill.Hundreds of recipes can be found online andyou are cooking in large quantities, it wont necessarily be that expensive!Another positive is the long shelf le of such products, meaning people can enjoy them well into .Christmas tree decorationsare an underrated gt - with people using the same items year after year, and even generation after generation, this could be your opportunity to leave your stamp on celebrations for decades to come.There are plenty of ideas online, but why not buy some cheap, clear plastic or glass bobbles which you can decorate with permanent markers, tippex pens or paint, before tying with ribbon.Baked salt dough can work just as well, while simple origami folding techniques can be used to transform a piece of paper into something special.A photo album filled with memories could be the best present someone ever receives.It may be slightly time consuming, but a collection of photos reminding your loved ones of a special time in their le is a timeless classic which will never get old.Photo albums can be cheaply purchasedonline or in store - charity shops are a good place to start - and companies like Free Printsmean you can order photographs for free from your phone.If you are a keen knitter, homemade socks are guaranteed to please as well as keep people warm through the cold winter months.Sloe gin is synonymous with aChristmas tipple, and as it turns out its pretty easy to make yourself, with some recipes only requiring three ingredients.Again, start saving bottles and by December you will be ready to decant.You cant go wrong with some Christmas baking, whether it be mince pies, yule logs or mini Christmas puddings.Pop it in a box and tie with ribbon and you have yourself the perfect gt which will go down a treat while people wait for Christmas dinner.If you dont want to give physical gts, you could make a voucher for an experience to take your loved one out for coffee or dinner once the festive season is over.Its something to look forward to once Christmas is over, and gives you a chance to catch up on each others lives after the busy end-of-year period.

There are just over  quangos in Scotland, which include Scottish governmentpublic andhealthbodies, executive agencies, non-ministerial offices and commissions.Read the full exclusive story here.Women board members appointed to Scotlandrsquos public bodies get paid half a million pounds less than their male counterparts, despite a drive for gender equality, The Ferret can reveal.Published pay arrangements for board members across  dferent public bodies, where appointments are largely overseen by the Scottish Government, show there are now virtually equal numbers of men and women serving on them.Read the full story here.Influential bankers,retired senior civil servants, well-connected industry insiders, powerful chief executives and former politicians - meet Scotlandrsquos quango class, the people who serve on the boards of Scotlandrsquos public bodies.Some roles are unpaid, and manyworkextra hours intheirdevotion to public service. title: letters-boris-isnt-tony-benn-new-jim-callaghan

What Mr Johnson is invoking is high inflation, stoked by shortages of goods and staff. With the UK heading back to the joys of the s, this makes Mr Johnson not Tony Benn, but James Callaghan, another populist, out-of-his-depth leader. ldquoCrisis, what crisis GR Weir, Ochiltree.ALISTER JACK OUT OF STEPIT is great that the Prime Minister now wishes to push forward towards a high-wage, high-skill, high-productivity and yes, low-tax economy. However I cannot be the only person in Scotland who wonders why this cant be reconciled with a real living wage in the proposed green ports in Scotland. The Secretary of State for Scotland has said that these high wages would make them uncompetitive .Possibly the PM should have a word with him Foster Evans, Renfrew.DANGER IN THE ELECTIONS BILLJILL Stephensonis to be commended for her directness in insisting that in the event of another referendum the Union side should have the advantage of question wording. However, her justication that ldquoYes had the advantage in practice stands up to little scrutiny, as the question used was the one recommended by the Electoral Commission. Moreover, having mentioned that a Remain  Leave question was shown by Professors Ford, Johns and Garry to advantage ldquoNo, Ms Stephenson concludes: ldquoAs a matter of balance, in any future referendum, the question should be "Should Scotland remain in the UK  Yes or No". I think we can draw our own conclusions from that.However, more important is Ms Stephensonrsquos focus on the Electoral Commission, whose aim is to ensure ldquoUK elections remain secure, fair, modern, inclusive and transparent. However, there are proposals in the Elections Bill, for a Strategy and Policy Statement for the Electoral Commission, which will set out the Governmentrsquos priorities on electoral matters and principles under which the commission will be expected to operate. While this must be approved by Parliament, it will be prepared by the Secretary of State, currently Michael Gove. The commission itself has said the proposals will ldquoplace a fetter on the commission which would limit its activity.Thus, the organisation charged with ensuring that any question for a second referendum is fair and not misleading will be under the control of one of the parties in the referendum debate. Perhaps Ms Stephenson will even get her way with the question for the next referendum, eventhrough the unfair, prejudicial, and undemocratic means contained in the Elections Bill.Alasdair Galloway, Dumbarton.THE ONLY HONEST QUESTIONTHERE is endless quibbling about how the simple answers "yes" or "no" might give advantage or disadvantage to those voting in a referendum .There are important decisions made every day by governments, management boards and committees on the basis of votes cast for a motion or against it. No one ever suggests that there is bias in favour of the supporters.If we ignore the bias implied by such inaccurate phrases as "secession", "separatism" or "leaving the UK", the only honest and historically justiable question for a referendum would be "Should Scotland become an independent nation again "Peter Dryburgh, Edinburgh.* A NUMBER of your correspondents have discussed the nature of the question to be put in any putative future Indyref.However, it has been clear since  that the only referendum result that nationalists will accept is one in favour of secession from the UK. Therefore their preferred format for a future referendum ballot paper would surely be ldquoDo you agree that Scotland must leave the UK whatever the cost And a box marked ldquoYes.And thatrsquos all.Peter A Russell, Glasgow.THE PRICE OF POVERTYBRIAN Wilson tells us that poverty matters . Indeed poverty does matter. The "rape clause" and the bedroom tax would not have been visited on Scotlands poorest familiesit had not been for Westminster rule by a Government rejected by the Scottish electorate.These, and other reactionary "hostile" measures such as racist immigration laws, are no doubt regretted by some supporters of the Union but the huge cost to our poorest families is, it would seem, a price that wealthy Union supporters are willing for the most vulnerable to pay.Brian Dempsey, Lecturer, School of Law, University of Dundee.COVID HANDLED BETTER HEREADAM Tomkinswill be disappointed to learn that on Tuesday, the Welsh Senedd also agreed to introduce vaccine passports and this is commonplace throughout Europe, as it is seen as a vital tool in encouraging the uptake of vaccines and to protect those who frequent crowded nightclubs and large sporting events.Nicola Sturgeonrsquos far superior handling of the health crisis in Scotland has resulted in Scotland having lower cases and deaths per head of population plus a greater number of jags administered compared to England, thanks to our much-better-performing NHS.It could be argued that the Scottish position would be even betterwe had had control of our borders and the fiscal powers required to introduce an earlier lockdown, rather than relying on Boris Johnsonrsquos fatal dithering that trashed our economy and resulted in the UK having the worst death rate and the highest number of cases per head of population in Europe, when as an island we should have had the lowest rates.Tories continually fail to recognise the four dferent health services in the UK, and on June  a House of Lords committee found that Mr Johnsons use of the Union Flag as a backdrop for coronavirus briefings caused "unacceptable and unnecessary" confusion, which is amplied by BBC Scotland allowing opposition politicians to immediately undermine the Scottish Governmentrsquos health briefings ndash a practice that is not followed by the BBC where in the UK.Mary Thomas, Edinburgh.THERE IS NO IDENTITY CRISISI WISH to commend Willie Macleanrsquos stunningly clear analysis of the Scottish British national identity . When it comes to football , I am Scottish. When it comes to world war, I am British. That analysis could provide the basis of a rational, flags absent, debate over what happens in the grey area between these two positions.My Scottish identity, for example, prevails in many issues other than football and includes our legal system, our education system, our sense of humour and many others.Michael Sheridan, Glasgow.A POLITICAL MISMATCHPRIOR to reading todays Herald , my eyes were drawn to the front page, just above your main headline. "Ross v Sturgeon" it read, promoting an article within the pages.My immediate instincts were to imagine a sporting comparison. Petershill FC v Barcelona sprung to mind .Kevin Orr, Bishopbriggs.SHAME OF THE FERRIES FIASCOWITHIN the living memory of many of us, the Clyde was the hub of Scottish shipbuilding, but under the care of our current Scottish Government we are now in the ignominious position of having to buy a second-hand ferry from Norway for pound million because Scotland cant seem to organise having one built here at home for an acceptable price and within a given time limit . And thats after those who are in charge of such things appear to have already spent about pound million on a couple of other older ships.It all makes me ashamed to be Scottish.Archibald A Lawrie, Kingskettle, Fe.Read more: The Union side should have the advantage of Yes question in Indyref

story: The BBC this morning claim Scotlands domestic top-flight will be halted for  days while the World Cup is played next year.Its thought that Scottish Premiership clubs are being consulted over plans for  rounds of fixtures being played between July  and November  before a pause in the league campaign.Fixtures would be not resume until December  at the earliest, falling one day before the World Cup final.As a result of the major halt in league fixtures it would be the weekend of May   before the final matchday.The Scottish Cup final would likely be moved to a June date, with the Premiership Play-Off final expected to be played in the first week of the month too.The League Cup would be played to a finish in February under the proposed plans - which have not yet been approved.The BBC report that lower-league fixture lists are unlikely to be disrupted with play expected to be continued as the World Cup is played.

title: scotland-faces-bleak-winter-soaring-energy-costs-electricity-shortages
story: The price of UK gas has now hit its highest level ever, rising by % in the past  hours alone with high demand and reduced supply behind the surge.National Grid chief executive John Pettigrew has warned that in colder months ahead the margin between electricity supply and demand would be tighter than in recent years.Last winter, National Grid was forced to issue a series of pleas to power generators to make more capacity available during particularly stretched periods.It was a surge of more than % in wholesale fuel costs over six months with gas prices hitting a record high which led to Scots households seeing their energy bills soar by up to pound a year from this month.:Anger as .m Scots households face energy bills rise by up to pound after Ofgem price cap hikeThe high price of wholesale gas has put nine British energy suppliers out of business in the last month alone as price caps overseen by regulator Ofgem prevent the full effect of wholesale prices being passed on to consumers.Credit rating agency Moodys has predicted that the surge in wholesale prices will result in more energy suppliers going bust.It is predicted that the next revision of the energy price cap which will affect bills from the start of April, is likely to rise signicantly to reflect the greater costs faced by suppliers.Customers are protected from sudden hikes in gas prices through the energy price cap, which sets maximum prices and charges for those on a standard or default tarf.High gas prices push up power prices in Britain as it remains dependent on the fuel for electricity generation.The Energy Intensive Users Group, which represents steel, chemical and fertiliser firms, said surging costs had already resulted in steel production halting "at times of peak demand".Last month the UK government confirmed a deal with US firm CF Industries to restart carbon dioxide production after a shutdown blamed on a surge in gas prices that had sparked a food supply crisis.The shortage of carbon dioxide - a by-product of the fertiliser factories - led to warnings from food producers and supermarkets of shortages in the supply of fresh produce. The gas is to stun animals for slaughter and in packaging to prolong shelf le.CF produces around % of the UKs CO supply, which is why the closure of the sites had prompted fears that shoppers could start noticing shortages in poultry, pork and bakery products within days.A fire at Britainrsquos main electricity subsea cable with France last month has further prompted concerns over electricity supplies this winter. The fire will reduce imports from France until the end of March , the National Grid has admitted.Prices of natural gas, which had already been at record highs in the previous weeks soared more than  per cent at the news.Gas production has also been  per cent lower in the UK so far this year because companies have been carrying out maintenance that was delayed due to the pandemic.The turbulance in the energy market has also been compounded by some of the lowest wind speeds since the s, which has dramatically cut output from the UKs , wind turbines. And there have been outages at some of Britainrsquos nuclear plants.Speaking ahead of the publication today of the National Grids official winter outlooks Mr Pettigrew told the FT: ldquoAs always you need to monitor those things because things can happen during the winter." That included including unforeseen power station closures and liquefied natural gas deliveries being erted to other parts of the world.He has said that Britain had multiple potential sources of gas, including imports from Norway as well as domestic supply from the North Sea.But he acknowledged that it would have to compete on price with other parts for the world, in particular Asia, for other sources such as liquefied natural gas.From this month, the three in four customers on default tarf customers paying by direct debit will see an increase of pound from pound, to pound,, while the rest who are on prepayment meters will see a rise of pound from pound, to pound,.Analysts at energy consultancy Cornwall Insight have predicted the next cap will mean the typical household will rise by a further pound to pound, and the impact of the crisis could be felt into ."The explosion of choice and innovation seen in the sector in the last decade has been fundamentally altered in a matter of months, and while all eyes will inevitably be on this winter, the need for an enduring solution to ensure that the gains experienced by almost three decades of competition are not lost," said its senior consultant, Craig Lowrey.Earlier on Wednesday, the UK gas price traded as high as p a therm. The trading price was p a therm at the start of the year.Jonathan Brearley, the boss of Ofgem, has warned that the cost of protecting customers from failing energy providers could lead to higher bills.

title: folk invited to walk through islands deal proposals for world heritage site
story: Community views are being sought on options for the future management of the Heart of Neolithic Orkney World Heritage Site , which includes Skara Brae, Ring of Brodgar, Stones of Stenness and Maeshowe chambered tomb.Next week, there will be an opportunity for folk to get an inside view of proposals, during in-person consultation sessions in Kirkwall and Stenness.Known as the Orkney Gateway Programme, the proposals aim to provide a more in-depth experience for visitors from home and away across the WHS and generate opportunities for Orkney folk through a more responsible and sustainable approach to tourism.The programme proposes improved signage, technology to monitor visitor numbers in real time and apps to suggest alternative attractions. Proposals also include “active travel” routes, e-bike chargers and welcome facilities, alongside coach permits and charging at some car parks.The programme is being funded with joint investment of up to £. million from the Scottish Government and UK Government, as part of the Islands Growth Deal — a ten-year investment programme jointly funded by the UK and Scottish governments, the three island councils and their partners from the public, academic and business sectors.During the in-person sessions, due to take place next Tuesday and Wednesday, attendees will be guided through proposals with representatives from project partners.OIC leader, Councillor James Stockan, said: “The Islands Deal commitment we have from the Scottish and UK Governments to support the Orkney Gateway is hugely gratying and reflects the position our World Heritage Site holds as one of the jewels in Scotland’s and indeed the UK’s tourism crown — not to mention the global archaeological signicance of the site.“But we must remember that at the core of this is a landscape and series of monuments which for many Orcadians is a direct, mysterious and powerful link to their past. And we know equally they are held very dear by people who’ve moved into these islands over the years.“So, as partners, we are all very clear that we want to gather local people’s views on the range of options that we could bid for through our final Islands Deal business case.”The consultation events are scheduled for Tuesday, October , at Maeshowe Visitor Centre, Stenness, from pm to pm, and Wednesday, October , at St Magnus Centre, Kirkwall, from pm until pm.If you’re unable to attend these events, further information is available at www.orkney.gov.uk orkneygateway. Comments can be emailed to worldheritage@orkney.gov.uk or posted to Orkney World Heritage Site Gateway Consultation, Development and Infrastructure, Orkney Islands Council, Council Offices, Kirkwall, Orkney KW NY.The closing date for feedback is October  at pm.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: information session to showcase self driving vehicles
story: Folk are to be able to find out more about a pilot project exploring the use of autonomous — or self-driving — vehicles .An information session is due to take place at the Orkney Research and Innovation Campus in Stromness next week, Thursday, October .The trial is one of four pilot projects running in the North Sea region as part of the Planning for Autonomous Vehiclesproject, which will explore how autonomous vehicles could interact with existing modes of transport.Folk will have the opportunity to learn more about the trials, see the vehicles that will be used and learn more about the potential applications of AV technologies.The event takes place at ORIC — the former Stromness Primary School — from pm to pm and there is no need to book.In Orkney, small AVs will undergo initial trials for logistics and freight purposes, such as the transport of general supplies, luggage, parcels, waste and other goods.These AVs will move at walking pace and work is ongoing to identy a shortlist of potential routes and uses.In a larger scale project in Inverness, an AV passenger service will be provided between Inverness Campus and Inverness Retail and Business Park. Safety is paramount and although the vehicle used will be capable of driving itself, a driver will be present at all times to take controlrequired.Widespread use of self-driving vehicles is expected by next decade and the findings of the project will be used to determine how countries across Europe can effectively implement them # including considering how they fit in with green transport and spatial planning strategies, as well as likely socio-economic impacts.Representatives from the project partners will be in attendance including HITRANS , More Work Less Carbon — a company based in Utrecht, Netherlands, who will supply the AVs — and Robert Gordon University.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: stagecoach pay offer aims to halt industrial action
story: featured newsStagecoach pay offer aims to halt industrial actionOctober ,  at : amStagecoach has submitted a fresh pay offer in a bid to prevent industrial action by workers in Orkney and across the Highlands.Confirming its offer, this Thursday morning, Stagecoach Highlands said it hoped to break the deadlock and reach an agreement with trade union Unite.New deals will be put to Unite in talks next week covering employees in Kirkwall, Inverness, Tain, Portree, Thurso, and Aviemore.This follows warnings from Unite that bus transport in these areas could be #brought to a halt# this autumns, as its members ballot on whether to take industrial action short of a strike.In a release from Stagecoach, this morning, Stagecoach Highlands# managing director, David Beaton, said: #Buses are a leline for local people across the Highlands and Islands. We are committed to ensuring our people who keep our communities connected are properly rewarded, particularly after their contribution to the country over the past  months of the pandemic.“We have worked tirelessly to protect the jobs of our people during the pandemic and done everything we reasonably can to hold constructive discussions with Unite to reach a sensible and sustainable pay agreement across our bus depots.“We are leaving no stone unturned in a bid to reach a settlement. That is why we are putting a fresh pay offer to Unite in talks scheduled to take place next week.”According to Stagecoach, bus services are facing a continuing challenging financial environment with passenger levels signicantly down on pre-COVID levels. Passenger fares are signicantly short of what is needed to cover the day-to-day costs of running services without Scottish Government support.Mr Beaton added: “We would urge Unite to end the uncertainty for our people and the customers who rely on bus services.“Strike action is completely unnecessary and would simply damage the lives and livelihoods of hard-working people, including our employees, as well as the region’s businesses.#We would urge Unite to put communities first and talk, not walk.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: visit scotland to launch new trade platform
story: newsVisit Scotland to launch new trade September ,  at : amVisitScotland is set to launch a new travel trade  which aims to enable businesses to connect with key buyers from around the globe — regardless of the challenges of COVID-. Discover Scotland  is a new event series, comprising an online business-to-business event with five regional showcases.Discover Scotland: Reconnect  will take place virtually on April -, . The five regional showcases, known as Discover Scotland: Live Showcase, will then be held in May and September . Together, these events aim to promote trade-ready Scottish tourism businesses to key international buyers on the ground in Scotland.  In , it will replace the longstanding annual VisitScotland Expo with a new format designed to mitigate the challenges of the pandemic, build on the success of Scotland Reconnect   and welcome international buyers back to Scotland with regional showcases. VisitScotland chief executive,Malcolm Roughead, said:“Discover Scotland  offers an exciting new  on which to showcase the best of Scotland’s tourism products, allowing businesses to stay connected with qualied buyers during the COVID- pandemic.  “We have worked with tourism industry representatives to ensure that this travel trade programme of activity meets their needs in  and ensures that connection to international buyers remains possible # it is something we are very much looking forward to delivering.  “We fully support the Scottish tourism industry and are committed to helping businesses recover from the COVID- pandemic by providing opportunities for them to network with tour operators and travel agents from all over the world, both online and on location.  “The challenges of the pandemic have given us the opportunity to reconsider the way we deliver events Discover Scotland has been designed to meet the needs of the tourism industry in  and ensure that connecting with buyers remains possible through a new programme of activity.  “Our international visitors are hugely important for Scottish tourism and we have continued to engage virtually with those markets throughout the pandemic, encouraging visitors to ‘dream now, travel later.” For more information, you can visit www.visitscotland discoverscotland copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. should be safe, according to a new forecast from the company that runs the grid.National Grid Gas Transmission said that Great Britain will have a ldquopositive supply margin ndash that is to say it can access more gas than is being used during peak demand.It said that the country has access to flexible supplies of gas from abroad, including liquid natural gas , which is brought in on ships, and gas pipes from Europe.This will be enough to meet all the scenarios of peak demand that National Grid experts have predicted could happen from October to the end of March.It comes despite a major hike in world gas prices, which was caused by high demand from reopening Asian economies, among other things.But as in previous winters, gas sellers will ldquorequire a positive market price dferential in order to flow to Great Britain from both European and global markets, National Grid said.It means that British buyers will have to compete with international buyers for their gas.ldquoWe have a positive gas supply margin in all of our supply and demand scenarios, and there is a positive storage position as we enter the winter, said Ian Radley, director of gas system operations.ldquoWe have a range of tools available to manage any operational requirements that we might encounter.Meanwhile, the National Grid Electricity Electricity System Operatorsaid the electricity systemrsquos capacity should also cope with the winter.ldquoThe Winter Outlook confirms that we expect to have sufficient capacity and the tools needed to meet demand this winter, said ESO boss Fintan Slye.ldquoMargins are well within the reliability standard and therefore we are confident that there will be enough capacity available to keep Britainrsquos lights on.The gas system operator also said that it expects demand to be just . billion cubic metres , down from . bcm to . bcm over the last five years.This drop in demand is in large part down to a drop in demand for gas for electricity production, as more wind power is built.National Grid Gas Transmission is tasked with providing the gas grid across Great Britain and occasionally stepping in to ensure the system is balanced.However it does not itself supply gas into the grid.Around half of Britainrsquos gas demand is used to heat homes, another quarter is used to generate electricity.We want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our defect.She has witnessed the devastation wreaked by the mineral mica throughout her home county of Donegal.Thousands of homes dotted throughout the county, in the north-west of Ireland, are riddled with web-like cracks that stretch theof properties.For many home-owners, the cracks are so wide they can see and touch the cavity walls. vw,vw,px, px"Protesters from Donegal gathered at the Fianna Fail think-in in Cavan last month, calling for % redress for home-owners affected by mica Ms Owens, from Carndonagh, is one of seven people in her family to own a home affected by mica.The blocks used to build the properties were unfit for purpose, and the large amounts of the mineral caused the blocks to crumble.ldquoOur houses were a slow burn, they were just a slow burn to failure from the very start, Ms Owens said.More than  years ago, she spotted cracks in the walls of her home and then heard about the defective blocks.ldquoMy brother heard someone say they had problems with their blocks, so I phoned them and he came to my house, and he said he knew someone  with the same issue and it wasnrsquot long before my house was filled with people who had the same problems, she added.Within two years, the Mica Action Group was formed.ldquoThe Mica Action Group provided all the foundation for a lt-off because we told people what mica was, Ms Owens said. ldquoPeople didnrsquot want to know about it or hear us and it took years to make them aware of this complicated material.Some four years ago, she spent , euro out of her pension to demolish the outside walls of her home and have them replaced.ldquoNow, the inside walls of my house are cracking and I donrsquot know how much mica are in those walls.ldquoMy house is now failing again and I am scared stf of going to my new insurers as it has no value again. I canrsquot sell it and I flushed my hard-earned money down the toilet.ldquoThe very walls that hold the structural integrity to my house is failing.The September Protest at Leinster House was a steady reminder that Mica Crisis wasnt going away.On Friday we will alltogether because we cant wait any longer. We need #percentredress now#MicaProtest #MicaRedress pic yimMdfCeoYmdash Mica Action GroupOctober , The campaign group has been calling on the Government to introduce a % redress initiative after it rejected its Defective Block Scheme, which offered to pay % of the home-ownersrsquo costs.The campaign escalated around six months ago when a group of protesters gathered outside a building site in Carndonagh in an attempt to prevent a lorry from entering the area.After that, Ms Owens said they took the campaign from her kitchen table to the Cabinet table.ldquoThe Government said in the latest paper that they will pay % for the cost of the remediation but they wonrsquot pay % for the demolitions, she added.ldquoTheyrsquore saying they wonrsquot pay % for the very worst of homes that must be demolished.ldquoItrsquos real slap in the face to the very worst-affected home-owners. story: TV star Douglas Henshall has today unveiled a plaque in his name as a thanks from Shetland for the success of the namesake TV series and the boost it has given tourism.The plaque was unveiled by Mr Henshall in the road outside his fictional home in the show, The Lodberries, a site that has become one of pilgrimage for fans of the series who visit.He was joined by Steve Mathieson, VisitScotland development manager and Malcolm Bell, Convener of Shetland Islands Council. said: #I don’t think anyone could have guessed when we first came here that Shetland would become such a loved show that it would tempt people from all over the globe to come and see for themselves the beauty of this place.#It’s been our privilege to come and work here for the last  years and for our work to be commemorated in this way by VisitScotland and Shetland Islands Council is both wonderfully surprising and genuinely touching.”, out Friday.A Shetland poet has had work included in a national virtual exhibition after being chosen from hundreds of entries. title: sixern utilises century old technology
story: took to the sea this past weekend with weather conditions permitting the use of a centuries old sail technology to improve stability in strong winds.The vessel, built in  by craftsmen Jack Duncan and Robbie Tait in the boat shed next to the Shetland Museum, features a traditional lug sail that rises to a peak towards the stern of the boat.Those sails in former times sometimes had a special row of reef points placed higher up so as to remove this peak and make the sail more or less square.This was called a #squaring reef# and is what crew used during her weekend voyage.Crew member Brian Wishart said: #When taken in it has the effect of making the boat better balanced steadier and more manageable in strong winds and heavy seas, and Saturday provided a good opportunity to try it out.#Since it is perhaps  years since the far haaf fishing was common, it is unlikely that this particular device has been used since then and we all felt delighted at how well the boat responded, yet I think a little awed by the signicance of the vast intervening period and the changes in particular to Shetland boats, their history, and evolution over that time.#, out Friday....TV star Douglas Henshall has today unveiled a plaque in his name as a thanks from Shetland for the success of the namesake TV series#A number of drivers have been charged with alleged driving offences following a road safety enforcement weekend in Shetland.Eric Gray Services has been given a £ donation to buy a specialist bike for adults with autism and learning disabilities. title: norrie t macdonald crofts have become the the bitcoin of the
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineYes, it’s more of a hobby than a full-time commitment, but it’s ‘in the blood’.. But were it not for Murdo Dan’s job as a joiner and Chrissie Mary doing a few shts as a carer, their economic ‘situation’ would be very dficult indeed.To supplement their income, they have decided to use their meagre savings, borrow a not insignicant sum from their local bank, and apply to stick a couple of pods on the croft.Meanwhile, Nigel and Pippa saw a croft for sale in the Sunday Times Property Section for what they thought was a snip at £k and decided to use part of a trust fund to purchase it as a commercial investment.They thought that they could also capitalise on the local tourist ‘boom’ and have applied to turn the derelict croft house into a vegan cafe and craft shop and also to stick several pods on their newly acquired croft to offer a ‘holistic getaway’ for their jet-set pals.Do you, and I certainly don’t mean to pre-judge anyone who reads this paperthink that their ‘cases’ should be treated any dferently by the local planning authorities If the answer is “yes”, then think again.Too dficult a scenario to judge Try this one.Should an application to build a couple of pods on a croft, which is basically  per cent bog, in the middle of Ranish and has no view of anywhere except adjacent croft bog, be given any additional merit over a similar application in beautul Scaristavore or Ardroil where ‘breathtaking scenery’ will be the selling tagline Wrong again.As a member of the local planning board here in the Western Isles, I’m more than well aware of what my responsibilities are and it’s certainly not to pre-judge any applications based on my own preconceptions, or prejudicesof what should or shouldn’t be allowed.I’ve to stick to the guidelines and the training I’ve been given, understand what’s expected of meand to base my decision without emotion or bias. across the front pages of this paper and others, on social media and the television news, can influence any of my our decisions.The capitalist playground which crofting tenure has now become, and the seismic change in the scale of speculation on ‘marketable’ properties available, is in danger of knocking the fragile socio-economic balance of the west of Scotland even further off its already very shoogly axis.Crofts have now become the equivalent of crypto-currency the ‘Bitcoins’ which can provide financial security for those fortunate enough to be sitting on ‘gold’.What’s being done to stabilise and bring a dose of reality to a market which threatens to get completely out of control How can single iniduals be able to own several crofts with not an intention to ‘work’ or develop any single one of them I believe that a crofting historian once said that this form of land tenure has become ‘the single biggest impediment to sustainable development in Western Scotland and the Highlands and Islands’.That wasn’t yesterday.‘Things’ are already well out of control.But who should intervene I’m not the only one who keeps asking the question.Apparently ‘we’ should legislate to address.We need, it has been suggested, to become Jersey or Guernsey.That people shouldn’t be allowed to buy homes here unless they intend to be used as a primary residence .Second homes taxation needs to increase signicantly and the additional income be used to support tourism infrastructure.From the Butt to Bodmin there have been ious proposals as to how to legislate to prevent the worst effects of tourism from destroying fragile local economies.Have any worked, andso, could they be implemented here to make any dference Let me be very clear.Tourism is hugely important to our rural economy.More so since Brexit and Covid.But I’ll say this again, at the risk of boring you all: it needs to be carefully nurtured and sustainably developed.We cannot survivewe turn our villages into ‘ghost-towns’#yes, I know…..for the winter months.We need a balance, we need the ‘tools’ with which to legislate properly and we need those charged with ‘oversight’ to take better ownership.We need, and I’ve yet to see any evidence of this, these same people to begin to take this seriously.For our future generations.They are the ones who will be impacted mostwe don’t sit up and pay attention.Now.

title: remember your roots skye plan is urged to recognise
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineThose were the comments of Roddy Murray, former Western Isles councillor and now the grazings clerk for Tarskavaig in Sleat, who this week voiced his concern that there was no mention of crofting at all in the ‘Skye and Raasay Future’ plan published in August with the full backing of all four local councillors.He told the Free Press: “There are  projects listed in the plan but not a single mention of crofting. Crofting is the basis for so many of the settlements on Skye outwith Portree, Broadford and Kyleakin and this should have been acknowledged.“There is quite a signicant impact from crofting on the economic and social well-being of Skye and Raasay. You only have to look at the , high quality calves sold for high prices last week in Portree to see that.”In terms of infrastructure improvements to support crofting, Mr Murray said the auction mart in Portree must be redeveloped to improve parking and animal welfare, and an abattoir facility must be provided so that livestock does not have to be driven to Dingwall.He added: “We are being told by the Scottish Crofting Federation that there is a huge demand for new crofts.#To meet that demand we either have to encourage landowners to make this happen or there has to be acquisition of an estate.“If we want to keep our young people in our communities we need to address the availability of crofts.”The Scottish Government are guilty of an “abject failure” when it comes to creating new crofts on publicly-owned land, Mr Murray added.Stung by the criticism, the council said they hoped to “discuss the plan further with organisations like the Crofting Commission” and would be keen to hear from any other interested parties.A spokeswoman said: “Skye and Raasay Future has been prepared with and by wider representatives of the community across the area.#It reflects people’s vision and priorities for the future, following feedback gathered through workshops and online consultations held throughout the year.“In workshop discussions, the important role that crofting plays in the identity and culture of Skye and Raasay communities has been clearly referenced..#Skye councillor John Finlayson said all stakeholders should be involved in “shaping, evaluating and changing” the plan’s priorities and he acknowledged the importance of crofting “in all its guises” across Skye and Raasay.He added: “Crofting is still a central part of le on Skye and while it is part of our history and culture it will also I hope continue to be a key part of our future and it is an important element of SARF.#As those who took part in the engagement to create the initial plan agreed, it is important that representatives from the crofting community are fully engaged in the continued development and implementation of the plan and I am confident this will happen.”

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20210930newstop tips for safe student accommodation
story: With freshers week around the corner and thousands of young people in Northern Ireland set to start University or new career paths, many will be on the hunt for rented accommodation. Northern Ireland has experienced a .% increase in average rental values this year[]. With the price increase, OFTEC, representing the liquid fuel industry in Ireland, is concerned that students may take cheaper accommodation options without properly inspecting the property. With this in mind, OFTEC has issued advise to help students ensure their accommodation is safe before they sign the dotted line. Raise the alarm – Currently, it is not a mandatory requirement for private landlords to provide smoke and carbon monoxide detectors, but the HSENI recommend that they do. It is a legal requirement to fit a carbon monoxide detector when a fossil fuel appliance has been replaced. Carbon monoxide is potentially lethal as it has no smell, taste or colour. Without a working alarm, it is impossible to identy carbon monoxide leaks. OFTEC’s advise is to ensure that there are working fire and CO alarms in the property, and that they are tested on a regular basis.Heating requirements - The Health  Safety Executive recommend that all boilers should be serviced annually and tenants should ask for evidence of recent servicing. If you have concerns, ask for a CD  Landlord Oil Installation Check which is carried out by an OFTEC registered technician and will give you peace of mind. For a gas heated property, ask for a copy of the annual gas safety check.Look for damp – It is easy to hide damp patches with a coat of paint, soyour house smells musty or you see evidence of mould, find out how the landlord is planning to fix the problem. Mould has no place in the home as it can cause respiratory problems and headaches.Furniture and fittings – Ask the landlord for a list of everything that is included and make note of any damage that is there before you move it. Check any beds, sofas and chairs are in good condition.Secure your home – burglars may target student areas because of lax security. Ask your landlord to fit key operating locks on the windows and lever deadlocks on external doors.  OFTEC Ireland Manager, David Blevings, said: “Quite often the excitement of moving in with friends can overshadow the concerns about the accommodation itself. We are urging students to play it safe this year and carry out these essential checks before signing a lease and moving in. “Asking a landlord about safety may seem awkward, but it could prevent you from living in a potentially dangerous property for the next  months. It’s vital that your new home is not a burden as you start your time at university. To find your nearest registered technician visit www.oftec.org

Credit: Alex GrimmRalph HewittTwitterEmailOctober   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailThe Irish FA has said it encourages Northern Ireland players to get their Covid- vaccination - but did not reveal how many in the senior international men’s squad have received their jab.Ian Baraclough’s side face Switzerland in Geneva on Saturday and take on Bulgaria in Sofia on Tuesday in crucial World Cup qualiers.The Northern Ireland manager, who has been vaccinated, has also urged the public to go and get the jab.Concerns have been raised about the rate of vaccination in the Premier League with only seven of the  clubs succeeding in fully vaccinating % or more of their squads.Read MoreCallum Robinson admits he is still not vaccinated as Republic of Ireland manager rules out ‘radical’ exclusion of players who refuse jabThe overall average is said to be approximately one-third of all players.England and the Republic of Ireland have also revealed there are several players in their squads who have not yet got their jab.Northern Ireland’s Leeds United star Stuart Dallas and Aberdeen winger Niall McGinn have said they took the decision to get the vaccine.A spokesperson for the Irish FA said: “The Irish FA, like all UEFA member associations, follows UEFA Return to Play protocols during international windows.“These apply to teams across all of our age groups and set out, in detail, how to comply with Covid rules and regulations.“Players and staff are Covid tested regularly whilst on international duty and we encourage all players to get vaccinated but respect any personal choice expressed on the matter.”Dallas said you can’t force anyone into getting the vaccinethey don’t wish to take it.“I can’t stand here and tell somebody to get itthey don’t want to get it,” he told BBC Sport NI. “I don’t think it’s solely reliant on Premier League footballers or anybody.“It’s your own decision. You might be for it, you might be against it. I was neither. I just wanted to get back to normality as soon as I could.“Some might call me a wee bit silly or naive but I’ve got it and I’ve had no issues with it.”McGinn added he took the vaccine as it was “just about being safe”.Baraclough said he will be taking the booster jab as soon as possible.“For me, it makes me feel better about things but also opens up travel in the world,” said the Northern Ireland boss. “Covid passports are going to be a thing for us all in the near future.”At least five members of the England squad have reportedly refused the jab despite organisers of next year’s Qatar World say, ‘Whoever is not vaccinated is not being selected in the future’,” said Kenny.“I’m not aware of anybody who has done this in any sport at the moment.“It would be a radical decision to exclude people based on not having the vaccine and exclude them from the international team.“That would be a very strong and complex stand to take.”Ireland and West Brom striker Callum Robinson has so far title: arlenes new job womens magazine columnist
story: Arlene Foster. Credit: Liam McBurney FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueArlene Foster. Credit: Liam McBurneyAllison MorrisTwitterEmailOctober   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailFormer First Minister Arlene Foster is pushing ahead with her journey from politics to media personality with a new column in Local Women magazine.The former DUP leader, who is also a regular presenter on GB News, will see her first column for the monthly magazine published this Friday.Reflecting on her recent journey, Mrs Foster writes: “The last time you read about me in Local Women Magazine was when I was being interviewed about my role as First Minister.“A week is a long time in politics and all of that, so here I am as your new columnist.“I’m hoping to bring you my take on some of the big stories affecting women not just here in Northern Ireland but across the world, and so much has been happening it’s dficult to know where to start.”Managing editor of the magazine Kim Kelly said the formidable Fermanagh woman was an obvious fit and had always been popular with readers.The decision to go with a column in the local magazine is an indication of the direction Mrs Foster sees her career going when she steps away from politics full time.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up DUP press officer Deborah Erskine will replace the former party leader as MLA for Fermanagh and South Tyrone when she officially retires from politics later this month.The column also touches on serious global affairs, such as the plight of women in Afghanistan following the withdrawal of US troops earlier this year.“When we think of violence against women in Northern Ireland and how we are committed to stamping it out, we should also think of our fellow women in places like Afghanistan and do all that we can to highlight their plight,” she said.Ms Kelly added: “Arlene is probably one of the best known and most influential women in Northern Ireland and has a lot to say about issues that affect women here and across the world. “I think people will see a warmer and wittier side to Arlene now that she has stepped away from politics, and we are excited to see what she will bring to Local Women.”.app-box.app-box h.app-box a.app-box img Download the BelfastAppGet quick and easy access to the latest Northern Ireland news, sport, business FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueDevelopment: The site of the George Best Hotel in Belfast city centreAllan PrestonTwitterEmailOctober   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailThe family of George Best have withdrawn permission for developers to name a Belfast hotel after the Manchester United and Northern Ireland football legend from the east of the city.It follows an announcement in July that local businessmen were working to finish the troubled project which had been hit by financial delays.Work on the George Best Hotel in the historic Scottish Mutual Building at Donegall Square stalled in April  when the owners, Bedford Hotels Ltd, a subsidiary of Liverpool-based Signature Living Hotels Ltd, went bankrupt, leaving investors owed millions.In July, a -strong group of investors announced they would collaborate with Signature Living’s owner, Lawrence Kenwright, to save the development and their investments.However, on Wednesday night, the directors of the George Best company, the late footballer’s family, said they wanted to clary their position, and said that they were not among those investors.“The family terminated all connections with Signature Living earlier this year and in fact are in amongst the creditors currently being handled by the official receiver,” they said in a statement.“Furthermore they have not and will not be committing George’s name to any proposed redevelopment of the site as may have been construed in the article referred to above.”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up The family added that they “maintain their belief” in the ultimate potential of a hotel “and desire to see a successful scheme completed in the city”.In July, Mr Kenwright said he invited the new group of investors to become part of the George Best Hotel property company, hoping their combined weight would make it easier to get funding to complete the hotel.The group is now chaired by Co Antrim businessman Stephen Kearney, who will now oversee refinancing and development, with Mr Kenwright taking on the role of CEO.After originally investing in the hotel in , he admitted in July that it had been “a turbulent journey” for Signature Living but there was now hope the matter could be resolved with the George Best Hotel administration.The GB Hotel group is also being advised by another Northern Irish businessman, Thomas Scullion, who is himself a Signature Living investor. He is the chair of the UK Accommodation Group , which he set up with fellow investors to restructure Signature Living#s operations last September.Mr Kearney had said that UKAG had “mobilised the vast majority of unsecured investors in supporting Lawrence Kenwright and have worked diligently on a recovery plan”, and said that “crucially Lawrence has handed over control” of operations.Mr Kenwright had admitted he was “ceding controland giving them final say in decisions”. He added: “We have faced a unique set of circumstances in trying to finish the George Best Hotel and I am extremely grateful for this support.”Signature Living did not respond to a request for comment by time of going to press on Wednesday night..app-box.app-box h.app-box a.app-box img Download the BelfastAppGet quick and easy We will struggle to deliver what patients need.”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Dr Black, chair of the British Medical Association’s Northern Ireland Council, said the number of people being diagnosed with Covid- remained stubbornly high, with the seven-day case rate currently lingering between , and ,.He added that face coverings and social distancing were still important tools in stopping the spread of the virus.“Our hope is that we can maintain the pandemic at the present plateau, but everything we know about Covid- suggests winter will make it worse,” he said.“I can’t see how we’re going to have a lower rate of infection because this virus likes colder temperatures. “People will have other illnesses and be more susceptible and they will be indoors a lot more.“We also need to consider the waning of the immunity from the vaccine, all at a time when the system will be under huge pressure.“If cases go up at all, the system will be overwhelmed, there’s no two ways about it.“Evenwe stay at the current level, there are no guarantees it won’t be overwhelmed.“I think the message to our politicians is to listen to our chief medical officer and chief scientic adviser, to listen to what doctors and nurses are saying.
