title: ‘Huge stress’ for families to find affordable home
story: THE growing need to address the districtrsquos social housing crisis is urgent, Slieve Croob councillor Cathy Mason has warned.She says there are many across communities who are struggling to access affordable housing which is having a huge impact on their lives.She also says she has been contacted by many people who are unable to find an affordable home, with some revealing that they have had to relocate to other areas after having lived in their home village all their lives.She said that having to move has caused ldquohuge stress for some families and can simply not be allowed to continue.ldquoFor far too long now, the current wastewater systems in Drumaness and Loughinisland have been operating at full capacity and are no longer fit for purpose. This is not acceptable as it prevents new homes from being built in the area, Cllr Mason continued.ldquoThere are many developers looking to invest in both areas to build more affordable homes that locals can rent or buy and raise their families and expand the community as a whole. However, due to the current wastewater system and the failings of NI Water to upgrade it, developers have not been able to build homes.She said there was ldquono doubt that those living in rural areas experience greater dficulty in accessing affordable homes due to house and land prices, land availability and rates of development.She continued: ldquoFollowing the Covid- pandemic, which has resulted in a greater demand for social and affordable housing, it is vital that we see a fully transformative plan for all stakeholders mdash including the Housing Executive mdash to meet the needs of our rural communities.ldquoAfter the publication of the Housing Executiversquos annual housing investment plan for , it is evident that there is still a huge amount of work to do to deliver social and affordable homes across the district.Cllr Mason said she was confident that achieving an increase in the construction of new and affordable social housing will benefit from Communities Minister Deirdre Hargeyrsquos proposed reforms of the Housing Executive which will allow the organisation to borrow from the market to begin the construction of new social houses for the first time in years.ldquoThroughout the year, site identication studies were carried out by the Executive for Ardglass, Killough, Crossgar, Saintfield and a number of other areas throughout the district. It is time these areas saw the delivery of much needed housing, the councillor insisted.ldquoAs a Sinn Feacutein representative, the delivery of new, affordable,and social homes for those in need is one of my priorities.ldquoHousing is one of the most fundamental human needs. It provides basic shelter, comfort and security. A home also affords personal dignity, a space for privacy and a foundation for family le..prettyPhoto

title: Ahoy%2C matey as children enjoy play ship
story: CHILDREN at the Little Acorns cross-community pre-school in the grounds of Derryboy Primary School have been learning the ropes of their new outdoor pirate play ship.The Jolly Friendship has been provided by the Energy for Children Charitable Trust to help boost the schoolrsquos outdoor play equipment.Established in  to provide a play-based learning environment for children, Little Acorns is a self-funded pre-school which supports  children from the Crossgar, Saintfield and Killyleagh areas and families from across the community.With imaginative play critical for creative development and wellbeing, Little Acorns has been working to grow its outdoor facilities to enhance the learning experience and opportunities for the children attending, but needed a funding boost to get the project started.Michelle Mullan, from the pre-schoolrsquos management committee, says outdoor play is important for young children in their personal development as well as their educational experience.ldquoIt encourages them to explore, get active, use their imagination and stimulate their senses through touching, hearing, seeing and feeling, something which has been more important than ever over the last  months, she explained.ldquoWith the support of the Energy for Children Charitable Trust, we have installed a new wooden pirate ship which will be the lsquoanchorrsquo for our outdoor play space which we will continue to grow as our fundraising allows.Michelle said said the pre-school is grateful to the charitable trust for its support and for enabling Little Acorns to develop a space for the children to enjoy, play with their friends and learn.The charityrsquos liaison officer, Gillian Orr, said it is pleased to see how much of a dference the funding has made to the entire community at Little Acorns which is providing a much-needed service to the local community.ldquoThis is exactly why the charity exists, to help local children who are most in need and to provide facilities and equipment to make things better for them, Gillian added.Energy for Children is a Phoenix Natural Gas initiative and that of the wider natural gas industry. It was established in  to provide financial support to groups and iniduals that may slip through the net of the wider charity network.Founded on the principle that all monies raised go directly to local children and young people, the charitable trust aims to reach deeper into the heart of local communities throughout Greater Belfast and beyond in order to really make a dference to disadvantaged childrenrsquos lives.Since its formation, the trust has helped over , local children and continues to help those who need it most.More information about the charitable trust is available at www.phoenixnaturalgas about-us phoenix-group corporate-responsibility..prettyPhoto

title: Best wishes to Knockevin staff
story: SLIEVE Croob councillors Cathy Mason and Roiacutesiacuten Howell paid a recent visit to the new Knockevin senior school in Castlewellan.Located on the site of the former Castlewellan Primary School in the town, the councillors welcomed staff and students and hope that they will be very happy and will be warmly welcomed by the wider community.Cllr Howell said the global pandemic had ldquosignicantly disrupted the education of the special school pupils and impacted on their learning, communication and mental health.She extended best wishes to school principal Sarah Liddell and senior department leader Gillian Rea.ldquoWhilst the children have been on the premises from September, there are still issues that I and Cllr Mason will be working closely with the school, the Education Authority and Newry, Mourne and Down Council to ensure that staff and pupils have the best all round experience on their newly refurbished site, added Cllr Howell.Cllr Mason said Knockevin caters for pupils with severe and profound learning dficulties aged between  and  and aims to provide a supportive educational environment where they feel secure, at their ease and thrive both educationally, socially and spiritually.She said the main school is located in Downpatrick, with an Early Years Centre in Dundrum.ldquoNow we have the senior school in Castlewellan which will seek to help pupils achieve their maximum level of independence in preparation for le when their education finishes, said Cllr Mason.She added: ldquoHaving visited the Downpatrick site in recent months I have seen first hand how happy and content the children are in school..prettyPhoto

title: Bid to save St Mary’s school from closure
story: GOVERNORS and staff have pledged to try and save a primary school in Saintfield from closure.St Maryrsquos Primary School is earmarked to close by August  next year due to low pupil numbers.The Education Authority last week published the closure proposal seeking any objections or support to be lodged by November .The proposal was made by the Council for Catholic Maintained Schoolson behalf of the schoolrsquos trustees.It states enrolment to the  year-old school on the Old Grand Jury Road has dwindled to  pupils for this academic year, with the majority in the Primary  and  classes.The proposal claims there is currently only one pupil in the schoolrsquos Primary ,  and  classes, two pupils in Primary  and no pupils in Primary .A spokesperson for CCMS said: ldquoCCMS has carried out initial consultation on the closure of St Maryrsquos Primary School in Saintfield, which is a Down and Connor diocesan school. Further stages of the consultation process with EA are currently underway.ldquoThe school currently has  pupils with capacity in neighbouring catholic maintained schools to support the continued provision for the pupils should the Minister approve the closure.It says St Maryrsquos is operating with five year groups in a single composite class and a further year group in two other classrooms.Over the past five years, the schoolrsquos enrolment numbers have fluctuated between  and .The EA say these statistics show no indication that numbers will increase to  pupils required by Department of Education Sustainable Schools Policy for rural schools.However, while the schoolrsquos governors, staff and parents s were informed of the closure proposal last spring, a statement issued by the school yesterday indicated they opposed the closure.It read: ldquoGovernors and parents have a great confidence in the educational provision that St Maryrsquos provides for our children.ldquoOur most recent ETIreport found education at St Maryrsquos to be of a good standard and our pastoral care has always been outstanding.ldquoSt Maryrsquos is an innovative school with new sensory and nurture rooms. These additional resources enhance the excellent education provision on offer to pupils. ldquoThe school community takes great pride nurturing our pupilsrsquo talents and interests and we will continue to do so. ldquoGovernors and staff are of the view that our school is a vital part of the Saintfield community and we are continuing with efforts to see that it will remain so for future generations.The EA said in its report it investigated other options, such as becoming a shared or integrated education and amalgamation with other schools, but concluded that closure was recommended as there was no evidence ldquoany other option considered could provide sustainable provision.It added: ldquoCCMS recognises the commitment of the governors and staff but the current challenging circumstances do not provide for a sustainable school.ldquoIt is recognised that despite the schoolrsquos best efforts, it continues to face sustainability challenges. CCMS believes that the proposal to discontinue provision at St Maryrsquos PS would not impact signicantly on other schools.It lists other Catholic primary schools in the area mdash St Caolanrsquos in Darragh Cross, St Josephrsquos in Crossgar, and St Patrickrsquos in Ballynahinch mdash as being between less than four to seven miles away from St Maryrsquos and which could take its pupils.The proposal also said closure plans had been put back for a year due to the Covid- pandemic.The SDLP councillor for the area, Cllr Terry Andrews, said he shared the concerns of parents and staff.ldquoSt Maryrsquos has provided first-class education to the community for many, many years and the staff are to be commended for their dedication to generations of families who have sent their children there, he said.ldquoI would encourage all local people to take part in the consultation to the EA and make them aware of their strong feelings to the proposal..prettyPhoto

title: Business owners urged to engage over town future
story: THE Downpatrick business community has been urged to play a full part in the consultation exercise on the continued economic regeneration of the town.Newry, Mourne and Down Council is spearheading the initiative and local councillor Dermot Curran appealing to businesses to get involved.While a number of politicians are in favour of appointing a town centre manager to work in Downpatrick, local authority officials are not keen. However, before any decision is made about the way forward, the council is keen to hear what the business community has to say.It was revealed last week that there are  empty shop units across the town, with Cllr Curran expressing ldquoconcern at the high number, explaining that as part of the consultation, every business in the town is being asked for its view on what measures could be taken to support its continued regeneration and to attract new investment and shoppers.The global pandemic hit a number of local businesses hard and while there are some politicians in favour of appointing a town centre manager to work in Downpatrick, others believe that the county town should not be given preferential treatment.Cllr Curran said whatever plan is devised to boost the townrsquos economic fortunes, it must have the support of the business community.ldquoI am appealing to businesses when they get the consultation letter from the council to respond and make their voice count, he continued.ldquoThis is a vitally important exercise and it is crucial that we get it right. We currently have too many empty businesses and this is an issue that we need to address. Revitalising the town centre is crucial.Cllr Curran mdash who is in favour of appointing a town centre manager mdash believes that Downpatrick should also have a vibrant body to represent tradersrsquo interests, one that could play a key role in helping attract investment and new business to the area.He said as one of the provincersquos county towns, it is disappointing that traders do not have a dedicated body to not only represent them, but articulate their views.ldquoAs we move out of lockdown and look forward to a post-Covid world, businesses will have an increasingly important role to play, suggested Cllr Curran.ldquoPutting the needs of the business community front and centre is essential and attracting additional footfall has the potential to benefit a signicant number of traders. Other towns which have vibrant tradersrsquo bodies or town centre managers have previously done well and I want to see Downpatrick included on this list.As ambitious plans are being advanced for the regeneration of the former Irish Street police base and a number of empty adjacent buildings, Cllr Curran said the current consultation with traders could not be more timely.ldquoThere is a need to provide a direct link between the business community, statutory organisations, a raft of government departments, key funders and the local authority and someone to oversee future development proposals, he continued.Cllr Curran said the Irish Street regeneration scheme could create new jobs and act as a catalyst for additional investment, explaining that in the short term, any help which existing businesses can be provided with will be more than welcome.He has also welcomed a pound, revitalisation scheme Church Street and hoped that a planned review of traffic light timings in the town centre could go some way towards helping ease congestion at peak periods.He added: ldquoI believe that the economic revitalisation of Downpatrick depends on a key link between the business community, local authority and others. I hope that this vision can be realised..prettyPhoto

title: Carryduff too much for Saul
story: SENIOR football championship finalists Carryduff against Intermediate champions Saul was the game at Liatroim as the SFC entered Round .Carryduff arrived after a defeat to RGU and with Saul losing to Burren, both sides wanted the win to avoid a relegation battle and stay in the Senior Championship next year.Carryduff got off to a great start with club captain Joe McFlynn scoring the opening point from play after winning the throw in.Saul quickly responded with a great play of holding the ball for Ruari OrsquoHare to get his sidersquos first point of the game. Carryduffrsquos James Guinness found a gap through the Saul back line and this was followed up by Daniel Guinness in the sixth minute.Ciaran Harney took a great finish to the ball to pull a point back for Saul before the home sidersquos Ruari OrsquoHare and Josh Connery were both booked.Michael McGrath got Carryduffrsquos fourth point of the game, but it was the quick pace of Philip Doran in the th minute that saw Saul get a goal and show they were up for the fight.The visitors dug deep before the first water break with Cian Clinton getting a set of points and Sean McGonigle, but Saulrsquos Lorcan Harney and Danny Curran both got on the scoreboard and at the first water break it was level, Carryduff - v - Saul.The next  minutes was very much Carryduff pushing forward, with Daniel Guinness and Michael McGrath adding a further two points each to their tallies, but it was the goal from club captain, McFlynn, that pushed Carryduff ahead.James Mahoney got Saul a point, but then got a black card, reducing Saul to  men. Half time Carryduff - v - Saul with Carryduff carrying a comfortable eight-point lead into the second half.Saulrsquos Ciaran Harney quickly got a point on the board and it looked like Carryduff were sitting back a bit, as Ciaran added to Saulrsquos score again which came from a free.Carryduffrsquos management team worked hard to get their men back into the game and it was not until the th minute of the second half that the visitors Carryduff got back into scoring ways, with Michael McGrath, which was followed up by additional three points, two from frees taken by McFlynn and the third from Cian Clinton.With this run of points, it was dficult to see how Saul would close the gap, but it was Philip Doran who again powered through the Carryduff back line to get his second goal of the game. Ciaran Harney got his fourth point just before the second water break.With the score Carryduff -Saul - , it was all to play in the last  minutes of the game.McFlynn scored a free in the th minute to extend Carryduffrsquos lead and Sean McGonigle added to that d in the nd minute.Saul were throwing everything at the game and it paid off with Lorcan Harney and Jack Fitzsimons both bagged a point apiece. In the th minute Carryduff finished the game with a goal through Michael McGrath, and added another goal in the th minute.Carryduff move into the next round as Saul wait to see who they will face in the relegation battle.Saul -Carryduff -SFC ND ROUND.prettyPhoto

title: Cathal aiming for climate success
story: A DOWN High School student is hoping to win a prize of euro, to hold a climate change camp for local young conservationists.Cathal Quinn, a Year  pupil at the Downpatrick Grammar School, is a youth leader with Lecale Conservation Association, a voluntary community group dedicated to safeguarding the natural and built heritage of the area.The group restores local beach sand dune systems, turns wasteland into mini forests or community gardens and campaigns for environmental causes.During the summer, Cathal was involved in ious projects with the group, one of which was a plan to create a series of climate change camps for young adults to identy and influence the decision makers in their own local government, planning departments and education system.Cathal and his friends, who attend a range of local high schools, entered their project into a competition for funding for such initiatives run by Coca-Cola across the island of Ireland.They successfully passed the preliminary stages of the competition and are now shortlisted to win a prize of euro, which would enable them to run the Climate Change Camps.Down High School is asking for local support to help Cathal and his project win the top prize, so that they can put their Climate Change Ideas into action.To vote visit: https:www.coca-cola.ie community thank-you-fund vote.prettyPhoto

title: Champs Kilcoo reach last eight
story: A DECENT crowd gathered in Pairc Esler for this local derby between Kilcoo and Clonduff in the second round of the Senior Championship.In the end, it was the Magpies who progressed to the quarter-finals, while Clonduff face Warrenpoint a round three knockout game this weekend to be in with a chance of reaching the same stage.This game wonrsquot be remembered as one of the greats but it was exciting due to the closeness on the scoreboard, even though for long spells scores were hard to come by.The Yellows made the better start, with Ross Carr opening the scoring. By the water-break, bizarrely, Kilcoo hadnrsquot registered a score with Clonduff leading - to -.However, on  minutes a Jerome Johnston free finally got his side off the mark and just three minutes later he did what he does best ndash found the net to send Kilcoo into the lead.After Jeromersquos brother Ryan had rattled the crossbar for a second time, Johnston was first to pounce to send the Magpies into the lead.Ceilum Doherty and Eugene Branagan put Kilcoo three clear before half time but Clonduff managed to reduce the deficit to one thanks to some good scoring from Arthur McConville and Eamon Brown.Clonduffrsquos Tom Close was black carded on the stroke of half time, leaving the yellows a man down for the first  minutes of the second half.This didnrsquot seem to matter as they caught Kilcoo out of position straight after the break, with Jayme Gribben finding the net for Clonduff.Mickey Moranrsquos team again responded and by the end of the third quarter it was - apiece with mistakes and turnovers aplenty in the game.Dylan Ward and Tiernan Fettes were introduced for the county champions for the closing stages and both made a dference to give their team much-needed energy.Going down the final stretch Kilcoo led by two, Shealan Johnston, Ceilum Doherty and the brilliant Ryan Johnston all on target.Aidan Carr and a Stephen McConville free kept the Hilltown men within range but it was their neighbours who finished stronger as Shealan Johnston and Miceal Rooney closed the scoring leaving the Magpies victorious.Despite Kilcoo playing nowhere near to their potential, they still managed to grind out a result and with Darryl Branagan, Niall McEvoy, Paul Devlin and a fully fit Dylan Ward set toto the starting lineup, they will fancy their chances of pushing on for a th county title.Ciaran McBride will rue the missed chances his team spurned, especially a late goal opportunity, in a game that was refereed excellently by Brendan Rice.Kilcoo: M McCourt, N Branagan, R McEvoy , A Morgan, A Branagan, A Branagan, M Rooney , P Greenan, A Morgan, C Doherty , S Johnston , E Branagan , C Laverty, R Johnston , J Johnston .Subs used: T Fettes, D Ward and J Clarke.Clonduff: P Gribben, L Branagan, D OrsquoHagan, T McEvoy, P Branagan, C Carr, J Gribben , R Carr , A Carr , T Close, P OrsquoHagan, B OrsquoHagan, A McConville , S McConville , E Brown .Subs used: J OrsquoHagan, P Wilson, S McGreevy and T McGreevy.Referee: Brendan Rice Kilcoo -Clonduff -SFC ND ROUND.prettyPhoto

title: Cormac enjoy his first days at Harvard University
story: CORMAC Savage was only  when he got his first experience of the hallowed halls of Hard University.Standing in the same place where former president John F Kennedy once walked was enough to confirm to the young teenager that this is where he had to be one day.Just four years later, the Downpatrick man has fulfilled his dream and is studying at the world-renowned Ivy League university in the US.The former head boy of St Patrickrsquos Grammar School has jumped right in and immersed himself into his classes and every extra-curricular activity and group he can possibly join.He has been in the city of Cambridge, on the fringe of Boston, since late August.Despite getting four A* grades in his A-Levels and having achieved considerable praise for his roles in school politics and as a Youth Parliament Member for South Down, he said he was overwhelmed to have been accepted into Hard late last year.ldquoEvery single day I think Irsquom so lucky to be here. I see the tourists who visit Hard Yard every day and they remind me just how special it is. I think all of the students here have a great awareness of the university and its history, the great people who have walked through these gates, but also our professors and how incredible there are. We realise that not only are we being taught by some of the greatest minds in their field but also in the world.He intends to share his excitement and his awe of the university with others.ldquoI was lucky enough to visit Hard four years ago and I was completely struck by the place, he said. ldquoI never thought I would get in and I want to give that experience for any prospective students coming to visit.ldquoWhen I see young people out with their families, I always offer to take photographs of them as I think itrsquos really important to show them thatI, a wee boy from Ireland, can get in, then so can they.As one of the , new intake students this year, the  year-old is indeed walking in the footsteps of impressive former students. Eight former American presidents studied there, including John F Kennedy, George W Bush and Barack Obama, along with leaders from all aspects of le, such as the politician and diplomat Henry Kissinger, Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg, the poet TS Elliot, actors such as Matt Damon and Tommy Lee Jones and a host of Nobel and Pulitzer prizewinners.He lives in a building on the corner of the iconic Hard Yard mdash the universityrsquos historic centre thoroughfare mdash where President Obamarsquos daughter, Malia, and actress Natalie Portman once stayed as undergraduates.Cormac brings a lot to the Hard table as well. Along with getting involved with youth politics and speaking at a debate in the House of Commons, he is a determined campaigner on social issues.In the midst of the coronavirus pandemic last year, Cormac helped to establish the Secondary Studentsrsquo Union of Northern Ireland , the first of its kind here, and was also central to getting former Education Minister Peter Weir to do a U-turn on A-Level grades after last yearrsquos controversial algorithm was used to determine grades in .He was made honorary president of the Secondary Studentsrsquo Union at the same time as studying for his A-Levels and also fulfilling duties as the Member of UK Youth Parliament for South Down.He explained: ldquoI had to submit to an entirely dferent application process to that of UCASand applied quite early, having to have it done by November  last year.ldquoI had to write two essays, one about being from Northern Ireland and how it impacted on my identity as a person, and the second was about me founding the Secondary Studentsrsquo Union and running our first campaign while working over the summer cleaning the toilets at Tyrella Beach.ldquoI also had to submit my academic record while writing ious mini essays and had weeks of essay writing and redrafting and redefining my work to ensure that I was putting my best foot forward.ldquoThe best thing about having to make the deadline in November was that I found out that I had an unconditional offer by mid-December so the pressure was totally off me when it came to waiting on results day in August. I was in a lucky position that I already had my flight booked for Boston  days after that.Believed to be the only lsquoRed Highrsquo student to have attended Hard, Cormac is the son of Gina and Stephen Savage. His mother is vice-principal at St Patrickrsquos.Cormac hopes to major in Government and graduate in , but has taken the opportunity to get involved in other activities such as being admitted to the John F Kennedy Junior Forum.Cormac was one of  people accepted out of  applications.ldquoItrsquos really competitive to get into to so I threw my hat into the ring not expecting to get it so I was completely blown away when I did. he said.ldquoThe group organises heads of states, politicians and leaders in business to visit campus where we moderate discussions and debates with them and a student audience.ldquoWhile Irsquom on the digital marketing team helping to promote the events, I could also find myself on stage later this year with Nancy Pelosi, the serving Speaker of the House of Representatives, which is completely mind-blowing.Cormac has suggested inviting Ursula von der Leyen, the President of the European Commission mdash a sign of his continuing interest in all things European.He met President Joe Biden when he was  after an opportunistic letter to him turned out to be beneficial.ldquoI was a massive Biden fan long before he ran for President and Irsquom still very proud that I predicted his presidency four years ago. I wrote a letter at  and saidI would like to meet himhe was ever in Ireland. My parents and I got the chance to meet him in Dublin the day after the Brexit vote.ldquoIrsquom more likely to ask him nowhersquos going over to Ireland, would he give me a lt on Air Force One, he joked.Cormac is still not behind the door connecting with famous people with his red hair helping him engage with TV host and producer mdash and fellow redhead mdash Conan OrsquoBrien when the former Hard student gave an address to new students.ldquoThe rest of the guys suggested we get a picture together as we look alike but he was great fun. The best thing was that I was wearing my Red High GAA shirt, said Cormac.While he has taken Hard and the US to his heart, Cormac retains his real love for his home.ldquoIrsquove really loved the adventure of having to adapt to the American culture and my three best friends here are all Americans. But what I have realised here is that I really love the place that Irsquom from and so proud of it..prettyPhoto

title: Covid
story: THE continued operation of a coronavirus test centre in Downpatrick could be compromisedvandal attacks in the area do not end, a local politician fears.The centre run by the Public Health Agency at Dunleath Park plays a pivotal role in testing people who suspect that they may have contracted the disease.Concern about the impact of vandalism on the centre comes after it was revealed that a number of iron bars were reportedly thrown towards it by young people who are also being blamed on ongoing anti-social behaviour at this part of the town.Downpatrick councillor John Trainor said the test centre and the Dunleath Park area had attracted what he described as a ldquospate of anti-social behavioural elements which was affecting its operation.He declared: ldquoThere is absolutely no excuse for our public service staff having to feel at risk as they go about their work protecting us and our loved ones.ldquoThere is a danger to test centre staff and their equipment on site at Dunleath Park and the overall operational ability of the centrethis behaviour continues.Cllr Trainor said he raised the ldquoserious matter with police and also appealed to Newry, Mourne and Down Council to direct its community safety wardens to the area in the evenings.ldquoWe also need a greater police presence at Dunleath Park as well and I welcome confirmation that this will happen, he continued.ldquoThose engaging in this behaviour can put it behind them and can seek something better. The alternative is to face the unfortunate consequences of their actions which I donrsquot think is something anyone would want to see.Cllr Trainor said ongoing anti-social behaviour has not only impacted on the coronavirus testing centre, but work to provide a new walking track around the perimeter of the town centre park.ldquoThe recent spate of anti-social behaviour threatens to damage the positive work which has been accomplished in the area over recent times and this must not be allowed to happen.ldquoThis has been such a dficult year for everyone and we continue to emerge from Covid, more resilient and ready to see more delivered in our local communities for the better. Part of this includes the new walking path.Cllr Trainor said the work to provide the new path is ongoing with people already taking an interest in it.He added: ldquoI appeal to those responsible for a series of incidents at Dunleath Park to stop what they are doing and realise the consequences of their actions. The testing centre in particular is a key asset in the ongoing fight against coronavirus.ldquoThe excellent frontline staff who work there deserve to be allowed to get on with the job free from threats of any kind. We need these people doing what they are doing as Covid is still with us.It has also been confirmed that the South Eastern Trust is hosting local pop-up vaccination clinics over the coming days as part of a Northern Ireland-wide drive to get as many people vaccinated as quickly as possible. Booking is not required for the mobile clinics.Today, the vaccination bus will be at the Ballymote Health and Wellbeing Centre in Downpatrick to administer first and second dose Moderna vaccines for those over  between am and pm. Those aged  and  will receive the Pfizer jab.Tomorrow, the vaccination bus will be outside the Market House in Ballynahinch with the same vaccination regime in operation between am and pm.On Friday, the vaccination bus will be at Comber Community Centre at Park Way between am and pm..prettyPhoto

title: Four goals for Luke
story: BALLYNAHINCH Olympic Town made the journey to Mountain Quarter hoping to find their first win of the season.They were up against a Ballynagross side who was coming into the match full of confidenc,e having not lost a match so far this season.For the first  minutes it was a close encounter, but Ballynagross found their feet and scoring ways.Luke Shields was the standout performer for the lsquoGross, finding the back of the net on four separate occasions.Philip Doran, Connor Marron, Shea McComiskey and Kieran Taggart made up the rest of the tally in what was a resounding win.Ballynahinch had their opportunities, but Ballynagross felt secure with Cathail Arnold in goal.If Ballynagross continue in this fashion they will be fighting it out for the league title, while Ballynahinch need to find a winning run of form soon to get out of the relegation battle.Ballynagross Ballynahinch Olympic Town NEWCASTLE LEAGUE PREMIER.prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C October 3%2C 2001
story: BISHOPSCOURT ndash Bishopscourt motor racing circuit is for sale, it has been confirmed this week.A series of adverts have been placed in national newspapers outlining the scale and potential of the sprawling complex.The Recorder understands the move has already attracted signicant interest among potential buyers, with no less than four firm bids already lodged.Last month, the Northern Bank changed the locks on the gates of the major complex after months of intense speculation surrounding its future and local planning officials announced they were considering taking legal action because the owners had exceeded the number of race meetings they were allowed to run.The current owner of the circuit, Mr David Beattie, confirmed yesterday afternoon that the complex is for sale, but he revealed he is currently working on a rescue package which he hopes will allow him to retain sole control.It has also emerged that he is due to meet shortly with Stormont Ministers Sam Foster and Michael McGimpsey to discuss his plans for the race circuit.DUNDRUM ndash Sectarian vandals caused thousands of pounds worth of damage to Dundrum Gaelic Football Club during a weekend arson attack.A UVF slogan was brandished on the near-completed building before it was set alight on Saturday evening.Damage to the building, which it is estimated will cost the club thousands of pounds to repair, included broken windows and burnt door frames.The fire had gone out before the incident was uncovered shortly before am on Sunday.Police this week confirmed that the fire had been started ldquomaliciously but said they were keeping an open mind about the perpetrators who they believe may have been youths.Club secretary Jarlath Carey said the arson attack was unusual for the club.ldquoWe have good relations with other sporting groups in the town, he said. ldquoThere is a certain amount of cross-community co-operation and that makes this incident surprising.NEWCASTLE ndash Traders campaigning for specialist closed circuit security cameras to be installed in Newcastle have been told the initial bill alone could stretch to pound,.The startling figure was revealed to some of the townrsquos businessmen and women during a meeting of Newcastle Chamber of Commerce earlier this week.The group, which has been lobbying for the seven cameras to be set up along the resortrsquos Main Street, has priced the system but warned thatthe scheme does go ahead it will be some years down the line.The Chamber carried out a survey during the summer, asking traders and residentsthey thought the cameras would be a benefit to the town.Revealing that there was ldquo per cent support, for the system from respondents, the Chamberrsquos president Peter Law, told members that the installation of the cameras would ldquoinevitably reduce ious crimes which have a times given the town a reputation.CLOUGH ndash A mobile telecommunications company has announced its intention to erect a mobile telephone mast in Clough.BT Cellnet has this week advertised plans to erect a . metre mast at Watsonrsquos Garagein Clough, as well as a radio base station at the Downpatrick Telephone Exchange at Church Street.The proposals have led local anti-mast campaigners to urge communities to take action before the equipment is installed close to local houses and offices.Martine Fulcher, who helped form the group People Against Masts in Bryansford earlier this summer, this week said people should be made more aware of the potential health issues related to living near such masts.ldquoOnly when I went to a public meeting and heard somebody talk about the risks of these masks could I make an informed decision about not wanting them near my children and home.DOWNPATRICK ndash Senior officials from the Downpatrick Property Trust have detailed their plans for the regeneration of a number of derelict buildings in the town.During a special briefing session with local politicians last week, Trust officials spelt out their development plans for premises at English Street and at Breenrsquos Corner.They explained their plans will result in the provision of several new shops and a number of town centre apartments.The grouprsquos chairman, Mr Cecil Maxwell, said that since the Trust was established in , it has worked closely with both the Department of Environment and Down Council, to make both groups fully aware of its plans.A number of local councillors have recently been critical of the Trustrsquos plans to redevelop Breenrsquos Corner, suggesting that the building should instead be bulldozed to help improve town centre traffic flow by widening the Irish Street Market Street junction.But following last weekrsquos meeting they have accepted that bulldozing the building is not an option and that responsibility for addressing the townrsquos traffic chaos is a matter for the Roads Service.BALLYNAHINCH ndash The man spearheading the campaign for a Ballynahinch by-pass, has called for increased political pressure to drive the initiative forward.Mr Francis Casement said the congestion in the town is getting progressively worse and fearsthe by-pass is not addressed more urgently by politicians, traffic could grind to a halt.Over the past number of months, he has been working closely with regeneration officials and members of the townrsquos business community and a series of meetings have already been held in progress the issue.Stormont Minister Gregory Campbell visited the town last year to view the scale of the traffic problem at first hand, but Mr Casement says that since then, very little progress has been made.Mr Casement has suggested that children from local schools could be asked to get involved in a major cross-community project and carry out traffic surveys at all the main approach roads to the town.Mr Casement said while Ballynahinch struggles to make headway to secure the pound.m funding to build the new by-pass linking the townrsquos Newcastle and Belfast roads, development of a new poundm by-pass in Comber is only weeks away.KILLINCHY ndash Tourism officials have been given a sneak preview of a major new holiday complex which is set to provide the local economy with a major boost.The first of  purpose-built holiday cottages at Hazelwood Glen at Lisbane near Killinchy was publicly launched last week and has been given the thumbs up by both the tourist industry and local politicians.From next Easter, holidaymakers will be able to stay in the homes which have been furnished to a high standard and constructed to comply with five-star self-catering guidelines.Each comes with central heating, three ensuite bedrooms, log burning fire and all the usual equipment which people expect in modern accommodation.Outside, each cottage has its own barbecue, with  acres of newly landscaped park land providing the perfect back. A pitch and putt course also forms part of the development, in tandem with new tennis courts.A series of walkways have also been created throughout the development and running alongside them is a wildle pond and wildflower meadow.Holidaymakers also have a spectacular view over the international acclaimed Strangford Lough, which is less than a mile away.CASTLE ESPIE ndash Every year thousands of Brent geese complete an epic ,km journey from Canada to Strangford Lough, arriving in huge flocks in late autumn.Next Saturday and Sunday the National Trust and the Wildfowl and Wetlands Trust, will host a series of Brentwatching for Beginners sessions at Castle Espie, so that members of the public can get a close look at one of the greatest spectacles of local wildle.Around , geese have arrived at Strangford Lough since the beginning of September and those figures look set to rise in the coming weeks.Although there will be thousands of Brent geese there should also be opportunities to see other species of wildfowl and waders such as dunlin, knot, curlew and oyster-catcher..prettyPhoto

title: Full steam ahead at railway
story: AFTER an absence of over  months, the first train of the Downpatrick and County Down Railwaysnaked its way through the countryside out to Inch Abbey.Itrsquos not full steam yet however for the transport charity, as the runs were for driver re-familiarisation following a long period in mothballs.Railway chairman Robert Gardiner said: ldquoWhilst wersquove been keeping our locomotives and railcars ticking over at regular intervals to keep them in good order, we need to do a few refreshers to get people back in the swing of operating them.He explained that throughout the lockdown period, DCDR had been carrying out signicant work on the track between Downpatrick and Inch Abbey, which has seen every joint unbolted and lubricated, rails changed, signage erected, and track geometry improved in anticipation of reopening.Mr Gardiner continued: ldquoThe first train out of the gates for nearly two years was former NIR  Class railcar, with a number of runs along our Inch Abbey line took place through the sunny Sunday afternoon as drivers Norman and Mike reacquainting themselves with the controls of this classic diesel railcar, familiar to many who used to commute to work from the mid s onwards, and as the Coffee Carriages parked at Inch Abbey.ldquoBoth railcar and drivers performed brilliantly. It was a pretty special moment travelling out to Inch Abbey for the first time in nearly two years, and then watching the railcar travelling backwards and forwards through the beautul Quoile basin was just incredible.Depending on Covid restrictions, the railway hopes to welcome passengers back and open the doors to the station again.Mr Gardiner added: ldquoWersquore aiming to get back in action for Christmas this year, subject to government restrictions and guidance, although we havenrsquot quite figured out the details..prettyPhoto

title: Horse show fundraiser for Uganda
story: THE organisers of Saintfield Horse Show handed over a cheque for pound, at a reception at Temple Golf and Country Club last Thursday evening.The money was raised at the show which was held at Danescroft Equestrian Centre, near Lisburn, on Saturday, August .Last year money raised from the horse show and the Saintfield Christmas Charity Ride provided a borehole for a village in Uganda, giving the community fresh, clean water.Show director Joan Cunningham said: ldquoNow wersquore committed to continue making a massive dference by providing a maize milling machine which will enable the farmers to process their crops for food. This will also cut out the middleman, thus allowing for their incomes to increase sustainably. The  Saintfield Christmas Charity Santa Ride will take place on Saturday, December .For more details contact Joan Cunningham on   or email joancunningham@gmail website www.saintfieldhorseshow..prettyPhoto

title: It’s heating up
story: THE temperature is rising in this yearrsquos Down football championships as teams enter the make or break knockout stages of their respective competitions.Despite a cagey opening quarter of their second round local derby, reigning senior champions Kilcoo managed to successfully overcome neighbours Clonduff and progress to the quarter-finals.Mickey Moranrsquos men will concede they were off the pace at Paacuteirc Esler, but with a number of regular starters set toin time for the next round, the Magpies will surely be a dreaded draw for anyone in the competition.Meanwhile, Aidan Robinsonrsquos Downpatrick dark horses made it two wins from two after defeating Longstone by eight points on Saturday.Downpatrick have made a resounding impact in this yearrsquos Senior Championship thus far after dispatching last yearrsquos runners-up Carryduff in their opener, before following that up with their latest scalp at the weekend.Longstone were entering the tie on a high after defeating Warrenpoint in the first round, who many had claimed would push Kilcoo all the way.Both of Downpatrickrsquos previous opponents, Carryduff and Longstone, will now meet in the third round of the competition where one will progress to the quarters and the other will see their championship title hopes shattered.Carryduff managed to bounce back from their opening round loss with a good win against newly promoted Saul.Last yearrsquos intermediate football champions could be excused for their back-to-back defeats in this seasonrsquos top flight campaign after they were drawn the vastly experienced Burren followed by the Carryduff side.However, Saul now enter the relegation battle and face the possibility of ing to the intermediate ranks that they fought so valiantly to climb out of last year.Joining them in the fight for survival will be Loughinisland who, similarly to their opening round, could not maintain their lead for the full duration of the match as they lost to Mayobridge.The Bridge now face Bredagh in their third round tie, after the Belfast side defeated Castlewellan in their opener but failed to beat Ballyholland to progress to the quarters.Castlewellan will be relieved that their one point victory over Rostrevor at the weekend kept their Championship dreams alive, but they will face stf opposition against Glenn in the qualying round.Also in the depths of relegation are Bryansford, who lost out to Glenn in their opener before they were defeated by Warrenpoint in the second round.In the intermediate action, Liatroim made it two consecutive wins to progress to the quarters after they defeated Darragh Cross by five points.The Cross will now meet Newry Shamrocks via the back door route with nothing other than a win requiredthey are to keep their promotion to the Senior Championship alive.Whereas it was a bitter pill to swallow for Dromara, Bright and St Johnrsquos who all tasted defeat for the second game in a row and now face the dreaded relegation battle.Despite Dromara losing to Saval in their second round, they will feel more disappointed at their opening performance where they should have secured the win over Clann na Banna after leading for long durations of the contest.Simarly, Bright will also be kicking themselves after they blew a nine point lead in their opener against Tullylish before they lost out to St Paulrsquos.St Johnrsquos also had their promotion hopes dashed in heartbreaking fashion after they lost their must-win game against Newry Shamrocks by just one point.In the Junior Championship, Kilclief ensured Teconnaught would remain in the competition for another year after a three point win progressed the red and green side to the next round.Teconnaught lost out to Aughlisnafin in their opener whilst this was Kilcliefrsquos first taste of championship action after they received a bye in the first round.Elsewhere, Ardglass bounced back from their opening round lost to Dundrum with a fantastic win over Aghaderg.All of the quarter-final teams will have to await the results of the next round before their opponents are known..prettyPhoto

title: M%26S hotly tipped to open food hall in Downpatrick as we reported in 2017
story: NEWS that Marks and Spencer has identied Downpatrick as a potential base for a new food store comes over four years after the Down Recorder first broke the story.In March , the paper revealed that MS could be the latest big name arrival in the town and that the High Street retailer had examined a number of potential sites.These included the former Danske bank premises in Market Street, but MS subsequently turned its attention to the former Irish Street police station which is to be redeveloped as part of a major town centre regeneration initiative.In a document published by CBRE, MS has confirmed that it is now seeking out-of-town or edge of town sites to set up food stores of at least , sq ft.Downpatrick is one of seven towns where the leading retailer would like to open new stores, with the others including Antrim, Armagh, Dungannon, Magherafelt, Newtownards and Carrickfergus.The towns are among a long list of areas across the UK where MS believes there is a market for its hugely popular food offering.The company said that it wants ldquoprominent sites on major roads with dedicated parking, adding that it will also consider moving into existing retail units.Currently, the nearest Marks and Spencer stores are at the Sprucefield retail park outside Lisburn and the Forestside complex in south Belfast, with the companyrsquos arrival in Downpatrick viewed as a major vote of confidence in the town.Local politicians say they are pleased that MS has not only retained its interest in Downpatrick, but recognises that locating one of its food stores in the town would be a very successful move.South Down MLA Colin McGrath, Baroness Margaret Ritchie and Downpatrick area councillors Dermot Curran and Gareth Sharvin hope that MSrsquos plans will come to fruition.ldquoThis type of food outlet has a following which would undoubtedly see people travelling to Downpatrick that previously would not have and that extra footfall can help other businesses in the town, he said.ldquoI believe this is a good new story and an indication that Downpatrick is being noticed by retailers as a place to do business and that is also good sign for local people.Mr McGrath is encouraging MS to aim for a location that is as close to the town centre as possible, suggesting the last thing local businesses need is displacement of footfall, confirming that he plans to raise this issue with store executives.Lady Ritchie said that as part of the townrsquos ongoing economic regeneration ldquowhich needs to be driven by a town centre manager, she is pleased that Marks and Spencer has identied seven sites in Northern Ireland for new food stores. ldquoOne of those sites is Downpatrick where the possible location of a food store has been talked about for several years, she continued.ldquoI hope that such a new store comes to fruition and that MS receive every assistance from Newry, Mourne and Down Council in identying the best optimum site which will offer local people a wider food choice as well as helping to pump-prime economic and business regeneration in Downpatrick.Cllr Curran mdash who is seeking a meeting with MS officials mdash said the fact that the retail giantrsquos interest in Downpatrick appeared to be as strong as it was four years ago was good news.He continued: ldquoClearly, MS has done its homework and sees major potential in opening a food store in the town which would signicantly increase footfall and help provide a boost for existing businesses.ldquoA new food store would also create much-needed jobs and hopefully open the door to other big names to take their place alongside the independent and family-owned businesses that we currently have.He added: ldquoFacing into a post-Covid world, the arrival of a major retailer in Downpatrick would provide everyone with a lt. More and more big names in the retail world investing in the town would illustrates their confidence in it and will help kick-start its future growth.Cllr Sharvin, who announced the retail giantrsquos interest in the town last year when he was discussing the area with MS management and letting agents, is urging local council officials to work with the company.ldquoMS has been looking to find an ideal location within the Downpatrick area for some time and needs to be at least , square feet with a good volume of parking outside. This is a great opportunity to boost the local economy within Downpatrick and bring a large number of jobs to the area that are much-needed, he said.Cllr Sharvin has asked the councilrsquos economic, regeneration and tourism department work with MS and its agents in identying a site that will meet the needs of the organisation and has also urge any commercial owners or developers to come forward to work with the organisation to start the process.He added: ldquoThis is too big an opportunity to miss for our town and we must all work together to deliver this..prettyPhoto

title: Minister asked to consider crossing at Ardglass school
story: STORMONT Roads Minister Nichola Mallon has been asked to sanction the provision of a new pelican crossing outside St Nicholasrsquo Primary School in Ardglass.The appeal by South Down MLA Colin McGrath and local councillor Dermot Curran comes after they met with staff at the school on the busy Downpatrick Road after a child was recently involved in an accident.Mr McGrath said theof children to school and people back to their offices and other places of work as Covid restrictions continue to ease is good news, but brings challenges with it.He said Ardglass remained a busy area, with new investment at the village marina and many businesses retuning to pre-pandemic strength.ldquoWith that, we need to ensure that St Nicholasrsquo Primary, which is located adjacent to a busy main road, is a safe area for children and local families, said Mr McGrath.ldquoRoad safety is everyonersquos concern and we all have to do our bit in ensuring our roads are as safe as possible.The MLA said the school was educating children about road safety and families were taking necessary steps to keep their children safe.ldquoAt the same time, drivers need to exercise caution and elected representatives need to work as closely as possible with the Department for Infrastructure to ensure we are delivering on our responsibilities, McGrath added.Cllr Curran said the speed of cars passing the school mdash which has  pupils mdash was a major concern for staff and parents.While a new electronic school indicator device has been erected further along the Downpatrick Road at the entrance to Ardglass to remind drivers that they are entering a mph zone, Cllr Curran said many are simply ignoring it.ldquoThis is a particularly busy stretch of road and it is important that everything is done to ensure the area in the immediate vicinity of the primary school is safe. A number of children have to cross the road on their way to school and it is essential that it is safe to do so, he continued.ldquoA pelican crossing can help achieve that and I hope that the roads minister will look favourably upon my request. This is a critically important issue that must be addressed.Cllr Curran said it is his understanding that the recent incident involving a child at the Downpatrick Road ldquocould have been quite serious and hopes that action will be taken to prevent any kind of repeat.He said pupils who attend the busy primary range in age from  to  and in addition to his request to Mrs Mallon, he would be keen to meet meet with roads officials on site.ldquoIt is a very serious situation when drivers are not obeying the speed limit, declared Cllr Curran.ldquoA new pelican crossing would require drivers to come to a complete stop to allow children to cross safely..Cllr Curran added: ldquoThe recent incident involving a child has reinforced the need for a dedicated road crossing and I hope that the Department for Infrastructure will respond positively to my request. The safety of our children is absolutely paramount..prettyPhoto

title: unionists must realise the outlook is abysmal says young uup member and former tory student chair
story: Brexit minister: We will use Article  to suspend the Northern Ireland Protocolwe need to do so   Jeffrey Donaldson says London is focused on protocol solutions that keep Northern Ireland in UK internal market, and seem ready to actEU does not budgeNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsOpinion‘Unionists must realise the outlook is abysmal’ says young UUP member and former Tory student chairThis is a piece from young UUP member Rowan Wise, a former Tory Party member:By Rowan WiseThursday, th October , : am  "       "  AN OFFICIAL PIECE OF TORY PARTY MERCHANDISE - A BORIS BREXIT FRIDGE MAGNET, AVAILABLE FROM THE PARTY SHOPTwo years ago, at the beginning of July , I attended one of the Conservative Party’s leadership election debate events held here in the province at the Culloden Hotel. At the time I was a member of the Conservative Party and Chair of the party’s Queen’s University Society. It struck me how vacuous the points made by Mr Johnson were, and also how uninspiring was the conversation offered by Mr Hunt.From that moment on it became increasingly clear to me that the Conservative and Unionist Party is no longer either Conservative or Unionist indeed it was this realisation that eventually led to my joining the Ulster Unionist Party in the hope of finding a political home.    " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...Rowan WiseToday it is dficult to countenance the profound and destructive realities which have beset the Union in the intervening two years. As I predicated back in , when discussing the matter with my then-Conservative Party colleagues, Brexit would prove that when faced with a clear choice between defending the province’s rightful place within the United Kingdom or siding with the European Union and it’s Irish Republican allies, the mainland government surrendered and handed Northern Ireland’s economy over to the EU.This seemed so glaringly obvious to me at the time that I could barely believe it when the overwhelming majority of the Northern Ireland Conservatives would not listen. Indeed they characterised my arguments as outdated, tellingly choosing to employ the tiresome rhetoric of the progressive movement which, paradoxically, the Conservatives claim to oppose.None of this should shock or surprise us as Ulster Unionists. We know all about the treachery of mainland politicians, especially since Blair. Yet now we are in an especially dangerous time, placed at the confluence of political forces that threaten to destroy the United Kingdom.These factors are not novel, they have been in the works for over years. Now wedged between the realities of the Brexit sea border, voter apathy among Unionists, the popularity of the Alliance Party, predictions of SF becoming the biggest single party following the May assembly elections, nationalism on the rise across the UK. and the absence of any substantive policy by the Conservative government to help defend the Union, the outlook can only be described as abysmal.A personal hero of mine, a real Conservative and Unionist leader, once said – in the immediate aftermath of a murderous PIRA attack – “ the fact that we are gathered here now – shocked, but composed and determined – is a sign not only that this attack has failed, but that all attempts to destroy democracy by terrorism will fail.”Margaret Thatcher spoke to the essence of Unionism, which is to say our democratic resolve. This weekend we Ulster Unionists also gather amid disturbing circumstances less obviously deadly but nonetheless equally destructive.We would do well to recall Mrs Thatcher’s indomitable spirit and her unflinching commitment not just to England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, but to the United Kingdom, to Great Britain.Those who decide to follow the path of least resistance, buying in to sound-bite politics and placing trust in either the cushy fake comfort of devolution or a mainland government so clearly uninterested in our plight, will hold their Unionism cheap in future years when the appalling nature of those forces which we so justly oppose seize our home: the province.There is no path back from the clf edge towards which we are blindly marching, we can only hope to change course. Let us reach out to our fellow Unionists, whatever their views on social issues happen to be.Whether or not we agree about levels of public spending, devolution, the contentious issues of abortion and same-sex marriagewe do not help each other out there will be grave consequences following May next year.In order to satisfy the ‘narcissism of minor dferences’ we will have, albeit inadvertently, assisted in the final barrier being removed to SF’s takeover of the province’s political and legal institutions. In short, we will have facilitated our own downfall.This does not have to be the case. We have the ability to reach out to our fellow Britons in the DUP and the TUV. Evenelectoral pacts are unpalatable, is it too much to ask an Ulster Unionist voter to transfer down the ticket to only the other Unionist candidates  Is such a simple step so injurious to our image when ranged against the very real possibility of a SF takeover I ask decision makers gathered at the UUP conference this weekend to seriously consider these points and that, in May, they recommend Ulster Unionist voters transfer down the ticket to only our fellow Unionist candidates: that is what voting ‘for the Union’ means.gtgt Rowan Wiseis a third-year politics student at Queen’s University Belfast. title: the plan to legislate specially at westminster for sinn feins irish language demand is disastrous precedent
story: Sinn Fein man Ciaran Beattie demands councillors side with ‘law-abiding citizens’ over Belfast loyalist bonfire row   Ruth Dudley Edwards: The bigotry of Michael D Higgins shocked some - I’m sad to say I wasn’t oneNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsOpinionThe plan to legislate specially at Westminster for Sinn Fein’s Irish language demand is disastrous precedentNews Letter editorial of Wednesday October  :By EditorialWednesday, th October , : amUpdated Wednesday, th October , : am  "       "  News Letter editorialThe DUP has been saying the right things this week on the Irish Sea border at the Tory conference.The DUP leader Sir Jeffrey Donaldson has in Manchester been at the helm of the joint unionist repudiation of the Northern Ireland Protocol.There can be no doubt in London that the internal barrier between the province and Great Britain is unacceptable to the full spectrum of unionism, even though some enemies of unionism are hoping that liberal unionists will in fact embrace the protocol.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...The DUP’s firm position of recent days contrasts with a turbulent period earlier this year, in which it talked tough on the Irish Sea border but seemed to do little about it beyond adopting supposedly strong, but confusing, positions against implementing the internal UK frontier and north-south work.Now it has, belatedly but rightly, taken a real stand against north-south continuing as normal while east-west is trashed.Unfortunately though, we are still grappling with the legacy of two badly flawed DUP decisions.The first was agreeing to an Irish language act, albeit concealed by its description as cultural protection, and so rewarding Sinn Fein blackmail of collapsing Stormont for three years. Stormont crises should never again be met with negotiation. Such negotiations lead to a slight gain for republican demands which, over time, accumulate to become large.You can bet that republican strategists are thinking of the next demands that they can use to topple Stormont.Asthe New Decade New Approach deal was not bad enough, SF threatened not to nominate a deputy first minister when the DUP changed leader. Edwin Poots and Brandon Lewis came up with a scheme to get republicans their cherished Irish language dream of a commissioner, who will be used to impose Irish in Northern Ireland, including in places where it is not wanted.The idea of legislating via Westminster to placate the SF nomination threat has, as Jim Allister says, left a “disastrous legacy” and set an appalling precedent.——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: qub research how did covid  get to northern ireland
story: Brexit minister: We will use Article  to suspend the Northern Ireland Protocolwe need to do so   VIDEO: DUP leader Jeffrey Donaldson and Brexit minister Lord Frost play down Boris Johnson’s failure to refer to Northern Ireland ProtocolNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsQUB research: How did Covid  get to Northern Ireland Seven people, who had been exposed to the disease but did not have symptoms and were not yet infectious, imported COVID- to Northern Ireland, estimates the mathematical modelling carried out by experts at the Queen’s University Belfast.By Neve WilkinsonThursday, th October , : amUpdated Thursday, th October , : am  "       "  The group of experts, led by Dr Gabor Kiss from the School of Mathematics and Physics at Queen’s, have been using mathematical modelling to track the course of Covid  in Northern Ireland, in order to prepare for future iants and diseases.The research based project examined the dynamics of the disease from March   until December  , using computer simulations and data provided by the Department of Health. The mathematical modelling estimated that these seven people imported the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus strain on March  .   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...A person passes a Dont help the virus spread government coronavirus sign on Commercial road in Bournemouth, during Englands third national lockdown to curb the spread of coronavirus. Picture date: Friday January , .Just over  months later, around , people have died in Northern Ireland from Covid . There has also been over , new cases in the last two weeks.Previous mathmatical modelling led by Professor Neil Ferguson, a member of the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergenciesfrom Imperial College London, has been highly influential in shaping the UK’s response to the pandemic - with this Queen’s research set to do the same. The study also estimates that it takes an average of . days for an exposed person to develop symptoms and become infectious to others, meaning that a symptomatic patient could spread the disease for nine days.Dr Gabor Kiss explains: “The modelling suggests that the outbreak could have entered the country undetected as it took some time for people to become infectious and develop symptoms.”“This research provides in depth data on how exactly COVID- spread in Northern Ireland and this will help to develop public health-driven strategies, not just in NI, but across the globe.”Dr Kiss added: “It lays the foundation for a decision-making support tool which could assess the state of an outbreak and help to advise on optimal interventions in the early phases of any re-emerging high consequence infectious diseases which are vaccine-preventable.”The experts also looked in detail at the first lockdown and found that the number of infectious people decreased rapdily after coronavirus restrictions were introduced by Government, such as social distancing and wearing masks. The expert team at Queen’s is now working on incorporating other aspects of the outbreak into their models, such as the geographical journey of the disease in Northern Ireland. This will give further information on the impact of localised lockdowns throughout the pandemic.The research was published in the Open Journal of Modelling and Simulation, find it here https:www.scirp.org journal paperinformation.aspx paperid

title: charities urge cliff jumpers think leap
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityClf jumping has been taking place for generations, but increasing numbers are now giving it a try thanks mainly to publicity via social media the outcome of getting a jump wrong can include death or le changing injuries.Danni Harding, from Cardf, suffered le changing injuries when she hit rocks jumping from a waterfall in . Danni, , who ran a successful security firm prior to her accident, broke her back and now lives with a series of debilitating health problems.She says: "I didnrsquot realise that the hot weather had made the water level lower than normal. I was having the greatest time ndash Irsquod jumped nine times, until I made that one wrong move and now I have to live with the fact that I have fits, I have a stammer and I have endless hospital appointments."I went from being a   business owner and mother to being stuck in my bedroom, unable to move. It felt my le was just taken away and it was down to one mistake, one wrong move."If I had been better educated about the risks, I might have made a better choice about jumping that last time in the way I did."During the school holidays, Water Safety Wales, a group of more than  organisations focused on reducing drowning and serious incidents, are encouraging jumpers to stay safe.In the latest incident at the Blue Lagoon, near Abereiddy in Pembrokeshire, a person in their early s had to be airlted to hospital with back injuries. It follows an incident in April where a man suffered le changing injuries after jumping from clfs close to Langland Bay, Swansea, and another where a man was recovered unconscious from the water after jumping from clfs at St Catherinersquos Island, Tenby. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityGraham Loveluck-Edwards has announced the release of his new book Historic Pubs of Wales where he relishes in some of the more colourful myths, legends and stories from Wales ancient past and oldest pubs.Included in the book is The Captains We, in Sully,a house originally owned by a captain."I have always loved old pubs, and we are blessed to have so many belters here in Wales," added Mr Loveluck-Edwards.Graham Loveluck-Edwards out snapping some pubs for his book "For example, the pub which claims to have an elephant buried under its beer garden, or the pub where funeral parties take a short cut to the cemetery through the bar to keep an ancient right of access alive, or the pub that claims to have invented pancake day and so many more."In all, Ive compiled over  incredible stories based around  amazing old pubs - is there any truth to them "Some for sure, but this book captures them and puts them in the context of history so you can be the judge."MORE NEWS:The book also contains a travel guide so readers can go on a tour around Wales and visit all the pubs in the book.You can find out more at www.talesfromhistoricpubsofwales.The book is available to buy now "As you can imagine for such a book the research was relentless and thorough, and a lot of fun," he added."Pubs have had such a tough time in the last year with us going in and out of lockdowns and with the introduction of social distancing measures."Sixteenth centuryinns are usually a warren of tiny rooms so being two metres apart has made opening and trading near impossible for many."So, a book which celebrates all that is great about our old pubs, which tells people their history, where to find them and what to expect when you get there has been welcomed by all landlords." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityNational Grid Gas Transmission said that Great Britain will have a ldquopositive supply margin ndash that is to say it can access more gas than is being used during peak demand.It said that the country has access to flexible supplies of gas from abroad, including liquid natural gas , which is brought in on ships, and gas pipes from Europe.This will be enough to meet all the scenarios of peak demand that National Grid experts have predicted could happen from October to the end of March.It comes despite a major hike in world gas prices, which was caused by high demand from reopening Asian economies, among other things.But as in previous winters, gas sellers will ldquorequire a positive market price dferential in order to flow to Great Britain from both European and global markets, National Grid said.It means that British buyers will have to compete with international buyers for their gas.ldquoWe have a positive gas supply margin in all of our supply and demand scenarios, and there is a positive storage position as we enter the winter, said Ian Radley, director of gas system operations.ldquoWe have a range of tools available to manage any operational requirements that we might encounter.Meanwhile, the National Grid Electricity Electricity System Operatorsaid the electricity systemrsquos capacity should also cope with the winter.ldquoThe Winter Outlook confirms that we expect to have sufficient capacity and the tools needed to meet demand this winter, said ESO boss Fintan Slye.ldquoMargins are well within the reliability standard and therefore we are confident that there will be enough capacity available to keep Britainrsquos lights on.The gas system operator also said that it expects demand to be just . billion cubic metres , down from . bcm to . bcm over the last five years.     This drop in demand is in large part down to a drop in demand for gas for electricity production, as more wind power is built.National Grid Gas Transmission is tasked with providing the gas grid across Great Britain and occasionally stepping in to ensure the system is balanced.However it does not itself supply gas into the grid.Around half of Britainrsquos gas demand is used to heat homes, another quarter is used to generate electricity..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: UK can meet gas demand this winter, National Grid says article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: masks return classrooms england stem spread coronavirus
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services.
